\nSiteimprove Sponsors Annual NAGW Pinnacle Awards\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJosh Ditthardt\n

\n

\n9/23/13 10:17 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove is proud to announce that they will again be sponsoring the Pinnacle Awards at the National Association of Government Webmasters (NAGW) conference, held from September 24-27 in Louisville, Kentucky.

\n
\n\n
\n

The Pinnacle Awards are an integral part of the NAGW conference, and in recognition of this Siteimprove has for the last six years sponsored this exclusive award ceremony. Celebrating and promoting the best innovations in government websites each year, NAGW is considered by many to be the benchmark conference for quality and innovation.

The awards are an ideal opportunity for governments to see how their site compares to others in the industry and as part of the sponsorship arrangement Siteimprove will be offering all entrants a complimentary Quality Assurance Check to assist them in continuing to strive for excellence within their web initiatives.

The Siteimprove Web Governance Suite is used in the judging process, and its cleverly simple and intuitive set of tools make it easy to review a websites overall performance. Along with the various awards available, Siteimprove will also be presenting a special Sponsor’s Award.

Should you wish to organize a demonstration of Siteimprove’s products or meet up with Siteimprove’s representative Josh Ditthardt at the conference please email jdi@siteimprove.com or call 612-259-0629.

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nResponsibility\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8689817536:\n\n\n\n\n\nGive your website a summer spring-cleaning\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\nGive your website a summer spring-cleaning\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n6/24/13 2:25 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

While most of us would probably prefer to use our summer time enjoying the weather, it can be the ideal opportunity to give our websites ...

\n
\n\n
\n

While most of us would probably prefer to use our summer time enjoying the weather, it can be the ideal opportunity to give our websites some much needed dusting. This is especially true for those who work in the education industry or who tend to experience a slowing in business.

\n

With this in mind, we've put together five easy ways to clean up your website:

\n

1. Remove old images

\n

While it’s cozy to have images on your website, especially your homepage, it is important to keep them updated, just as you would your content. Now is the time to remove all those old and perhaps outdated pictures, and instead spend some time in taking or uploading new ones that are more reflective of the coming season. Additionally old images can make your website appear like you’re on vacation, which could send potential customers elsewhere.

\n

2. Invigorate your content

\n

A lighter workload can provide a great time to go through your website and evaluate all your content. Get rid of all misspellings, and outdated information, as begin focusing on refreshing content. This period is ideal for reviewing your website’s content and checking to see whether it is still relevant. By spring-cleaning your content, it can also provide you with new ideas for fresh content to pursue.

\n

3. Check your links

\n

It is also a good idea to take this time to make sure that all your links still work as intended. There is nothing more annoying for your website users than being sent to the black hole that is a 404 page. While this task can be a tad mind numbing, there are tools available that can greatly assist. Also, consider doing some external searching to check for sites that mention your company or web address but don’t actually link back to you. By rectifying this issue you’re not only making it easier for prospects to find you, but it also assist with your SEO efforts.  

\n

4. Review your site stats

\n

The summer time is also perfect for reviewing the information gathered by your analytics program. With these statistics, you should be able to figure out what content has been most successful so far this year, as well as give you general indicators of what kind of things your website users are searching for. Bounce rates can also be useful in helping you to ensure that your website efforts for the remainder of 2013 are as targeted and effective as possible.   

\n

5. Restructure, reformat, restyle

\n

A complete website redesign may not be necessary but these quieter months can be used to take a critical look at the design and layout of your site. Is it professional looking enough, can users easily navigate it, is in keeping with your style guidelines? These are just a few of the basic things that can start thinking about. A good tip can be to ask someone with fresh eyes what they think of your site.

So while it may seem easier to kick back and work on your tan this summer, remember that giving your website a ‘summer’ clean may just give you the competitive edge you need to stay ahead for the rest of 2013.

\n
\n
\n

Why Do My Documents Need To Be Accessible?

\n
\n

BY Dave Schneider

\n

8. Apr 2014

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Admit it: “PDFs” aren’t usually the first thing that come to mind when you think about website accessibility. They probably should be. PDFs are nearly ubiquitous as a “final” document type on the web, and hosted PDFs are often the only location certain content is made available – especially for educators, the healthcare industry, and government offices. When they aren’t accessible, that information simply isn’t available to users with disabilities.

\n
\n

The lack of accessibility of online documents exposes website owners to the same risks as inaccessible web pages. Although we could address many different online documents such as Word, Excel, and PowerPoint, our focus will be on the predominant format, PDF (Portable Document Format).

\n

 

\n

Q: What defines an Accessible Document?

\n

A: A document is considered accessible if all users, with or without disabilities, can read and understand all the information it contains.  Every user should be able to:

\n
    \n
  • Understand the document’s structure
    • \n
  • Read and understand the document’s contents, including text and images
    • \n
  • Understand and navigate sections such as tables
    • \n
  • Interact with any forms
    • \n
\n

Assistive technology is only as good as the information you provide to it. If you don’t provide good instructions, the technology isn’t able to do its job. Providing accessible instructions (tagged documents) ensures that assistive technology can accomplish its purpose. Remember that there are also different levels of accessibility—not accessible, partly accessible, and fully accessible. How you build your documents will determine these levels.

\n

 

\n

Q: What Are the Document’s Accessibility Standards?

\n

A: It’s important to use the most relevant standard for any given technology, and online documents are no different. Here is how these different standards affect online documents:

\n

 

\n

WCAG 2.0

\n

WCAG 2.0 applies to web content. Although PDF is not recognized by the W3C as a standard web format, PDF use on websites is addressed by 23 different WCAG PDF Techniques including:

\n
    \n
  • PDF1: Applying text alternatives to images (Success Criterion 1.1.1, Non-text content)
    • \n
  • PDF3: Ensuring correct tab and reading order in PDF documents (Success Criterion 1.3.2, Meaningful Sequence)
    • \n
  • PDF9: Providing headings (Success Criterion 1.3.1, Info and Relationships)
    • \n
  • PDF11: Providing links and link text (Success Criterion 1.3.1, Info and Relationships)
    • \n
  • PDF16: Setting the default language (Success Criterion 3.1.1, Language of Page)
    • \n
  • PDF21: Using List tags for lists in PDF documents (Success Criterion 1.3.1, Info and Relationships)
    • \n
\n

The PDF techniques will be covered in detail in a future blog post. In the mean time, which standard is considered the formal document standard for PDF files?

\n

 

\n

PDF/UA (ISO 14289)

\n

PDF/UA is not a different file format, but a technique to implement the PDF format. The reason for PDF/UA (ISO 14289) is to describe how to create electronic documents in the PDF format in a way that allows the file to be accessible. The accessibility is dependent on semantic information in a document. Semantic information may also include additional metadata, like alternative text for images.

\n

 

\n

Matterhorn Protocol

\n

To promote use of PDF/UA, the PDF Association’s PDF/UA Competence Center created the Matterhorn Protocol. The Matterhorn Protocol is a group of 31 checkpoints that includes 136 failure points corresponding to PDF/UA’s file format requirements.

\n

Just because a document passes PDF/UA compliance doesn’t mean it will pass the WCAG, and organizations shouldn’t treat PDF/UA as a WCAG replacement, but utilize both standards.

\n

 

\n

Q: How Do Search Engines Handle PDFs?

\n

A: In the past search engines were not able to index PDF content, but that’s no longer the case; search engine technology is now able to gather much of the information provided in a document. The difference between web pages and PDF pages is that web pages are optimized for search engines. Many PDFs contain detailed information, and search engines love that detailed information. Properly tagged PDFs will enhance the indexing of the document, and make that detailed information much more valuable.

\n

 

\n

Q: When Should I Use PDF files?

\n

Appropriate Uses of PDF Files

\n
    \n
  • Secure documents
    • \n
  • Downloadable documents
    • \n
  • Print documents that need to keep formatting
    • \n
  • Documents that provide more detail
    • \n
  • Interactive forms
    • \n
  • Low usage documents (large documents, archives)
    • \n
\n

Remember these insights:

\n
    \n
  • HTML achieves accessibility better than PDF
    • \n
  • Most PDFs on the web should be HTML
    • \n
  • Many websites have a print to PDF feature
    • \n
  • Some documents (Word, Excel, etc.), should be PDFs
    • \n
\n

 

\n

Who is responsible for making the PDF accessible?

\n

\n

Training

\n

Document content producers are usually different from your Web content producers. You will need to modify your training accordingly. Train producers on the appropriate techniques to save tagged PDFs.

\n

\n

Templates

\n

Provide template files that meet both accessibility and branding guidelines. Move forward with new documents—make them accessible. Don’t try and convert all of your old files right away, convert them on an as-needed basis.

\n

\n

Remediation

\n

Once you have created accessible templates for distribution, think about how you will update existing documents. Here are a few things to consider:

\n
    \n
  • Will you be providing accessible documents on an “as needed” basis?
    • \n
  • How often do you need to provide an accessible document?
    • \n
  • What is your turn-around time for providing an accessible document?
    • \n
  • Do you need to engage an outside provider to assist with document remediation?
    • \n
\n

 

\n

Q: Where Do I Start?

\n

A: We’re offering a free webinar on getting started with document accessibility. The webinar is a valuable way to understand why your documents need to be accessible. We’ll discuss:

\n
    \n
  • What is an Accessible Document?
    • \n
  • Accessible Document Standards
    • \n
  • PDFs and Search Engines
    • \n
  • When to provide PDFs online
    • \n
  • Who is responsible for PDF accessibility?
    • \n
\n

 

\n

We will then follow up with webinars on creating accessible documents in Word and InDesign.

\n

Sign up for our webinar, “Why Making PDF Accessible Documents is Important” here.

\n

\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Top-Down, Bottom-up: 2 Approaches to Better Web Governance at Your University

\n

I have heard it said that if a university was a country, it would last about a week before breaking apart in civil war. At first brush it sounded ridiculous, but now I think it actually makes a good bit of sense. Think about it – a university: Has a large population. Is highly diverse….

\n
\n

BY Dave Schneider

\n

9. Apr 2014

\n
\n
\nMore\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Say goodbye to inaccessible PDFs on your website

\n

”We can’t upload PDFs to our website because PDFs are not accessible“ and “We have to provide an accessible version of our PDFs since it is not possible to make PDFs accessible“ are both common dilemmas experienced among web teams. Perhaps these are sentences you’ve heard or even used yourself? It is a common misunderstanding…

\n
\n

BY Dave Schneider

\n

9. Apr 2014

\n
\n
\nMore\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

How to Stop Putting Out Fires and be Proactive With Your Website

\n

Everyone knows reactive marketing is ineffective, but far too many marketers are buried deep under a pile of emergencies to even think about strategic planning. What do you do when your boss comes to your desk every day to light your hair on fire with another emergency? Stop Dropping and Rolling The first step is…

\n
\n

BY Dave Schneider

\n

8. Apr 2014

\n\n\n\n\n\n 8718697756:\n\n\n\n\n\nSearch Solutions for Mobile Websites\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n

\nSearch Solutions for Mobile Websites\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n10/24/12 3:42 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you planning to launch a mobile version of your website? Here are a few ideas for the design of the search function for the mobile site.

\n
\n\n
\n

The user's needs and behavior are influenced by their physical surroundings when they use mobile sites. This means they may have to deal with clumsy fingers, background noise, and limited time.  Don't count on mobile users to be sitting at a desk in a silent atmosphere, since they're just as likely to be on a shaky bus or in the middle of a jostling crowd.

\n

Also unique to mobile is the fact that space on the screen is limited. Help them out by reducing the content to include only the most important elements to free up screen space for large buttons.

\n

Adjust the search function to the surroundings:

\n
    \n
  • Save clicks by presenting facts directly on the search page.
    • \n
  • Make room for showing the search results by removing categories, filters, breadcrumbs and other additional functionality.
    • \n
  • The essential elements that need to be presents are: a search box, a search button, and links to the search results with a useful description for each.
    • \n
\n

Give me the facts right here, right now.

\n

A lot of research is being done on the informational needs of mobile users. I highly recommend you check out an overview blog post by Tyler Tate.

\n

Diary-based research shows us the wide range of ways users use their devices for information seeking purposes. Other articles take the information needs that are known to be present for users via a desktop and explore whether the same needs are seen when using mobile devices.

\n

When you work on building a good search function for a mobile website you can focus on the differences in information needs depending on which platform is being used.

\n

On mobile devices, one type of information needs stands out as the most important: fact-finding.

\n

This means that facts about your organization need to be easy to find via your search - one more reason to show facts such as contact information, opening hours or event information, directly on the search results page so users do not need to actually click away form the result page. 

\n

Take control of the ranking for the search results to make sure that facts come first. Consider setting up quicklinks for the most frequent search terms and directly show maps, phone numbers or an overview of opening hours.  

\n

Push your messages out to users while they are waiting.

\n

Mobile devices go with you everywhere, so they are available to users while they are waiting or bored. The second priority for the result ranking is campaigns, news and other pages with messages you would like to push out.

\n

Ideally, if your site can detect where users are, adjust the ranking to the context the users are currently in.

\n

When users are at home, push pages with news, campaigns and events highest. When users are out, prioritize facts, so they are easy to find and not hidden behind an extra click. 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8718697306:\n\n\n\n\n\nRoles and responsibilities in Web Governance\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nRoles and responsibilities in Web Governance\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n10/10/12 3:59 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Do all employees in your organization know what their role is, and what is expected of them? Do employees know who to ask questions outside their own work area? Do you know what every employee in your web team does?

\n
\n\n
\n

I've previously written an introduction to Web Governance and a short guide to mapping your current Web Governance. As mentioned in those blog posts, Web Governance is all about having structures for decisions and responsibilities in place, which ensure that all work done on the organization's website is aligned with business goals.

\n

One of the corner stones of good Web Governance is that everybody involved in the company website is aware of their role. This is true no matter if you are a web developer spending all your time working on the website or if you are an editor spending just 1 hour a week on updating content within your work area.

\n

Web Governance roles

\n

When you work with roles in terms of the website, you'll have to make sure that all aspects of the website are thought through. Web Governance is not only governing day to day decisions, such as who will write the next blog post or do we need more RAM in our web servers. Your Web Governance should also cover who decides how web content is organized, which criteria needs to be met before you'll have to get a new website, and who is responsible for following up on web strategic goals.

\n

The roles that are on an organizations web team depends on the size of the organization and the people in the team, but some typical roles include:

\n
    \n
  • Website owner
    • \n
  • Project manager
    • \n
  • Web editor
    • \n
  • Web developer
    • \n
  • Server administrator
    • \n
  • Information architect
    • \n
  • Analytics specialist
    • \n
  • Usability specialist
    • \n
\n

Depending on the individual organization you can have a lot more roles, but you can also have colleagues who have more than one of these roles. It is a good idea to map all the roles of your organization and put a name on the role, so that each person is aware of their roles.

\n

Different responsibilities

\n

Uncovering and assigning all the web related roles for the organization is only one small step on the way. To make sure that each person is aware of their responsibilities and what is expected of them, it is important that the responsibilities of the role in relation with individual web tasks are clearly defined.

\n

One way to do this is to use a responsibility-assignment-matrix (RACI), where each role is assigned one of the following four responsibility types for each task.

\n
    \n
  • Responsible - The persons who do the actual work on the task. Often this will be web editors, web developers or the like.
    • \n
  • Accountable - The one person who is held accountable for the timely completion of the task. This will often be the person delegating the task to the Responsible. Typically this is a team leader or project manager.
    • \n
  • Consulted - Those who are asked for advice or opinions. Typically information architects or experts in a two way communication.
    • \n
  • Informed - Those who are informed or kept up-to-date on progress. For example, team members not involved in the task or from related teams.
    • \n
\n

By filling out such a matrix with all web related tasks you can make sure that all team members are aware of their responsibilities and that web activities are kept on track.

\n

When all members of a web team are aware of their roles and responsibilities, the team will function better and make fewer errors.

\n

More Web Governance

\n

If you have written down the roles and responsibilities, possibly in a responsibility-assignment-matrix, you are well on your way with ensuring Web Governance, but there is still a lot of ground to cover. In a future blog post I'll cover Web Governance Policies and procedures.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8718664026:\n\n\n\n\n\nThe Web Designer's Guide on How to Create Accessible GUIs\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\nThe Web Designer's Guide on How to Create Accessible GUIs\n

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n12/12/12 2:58 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As a web designer, several accessibility criteria are especially important to help you ensure as many users as possible can use your web application.

\n
\n\n
\n
\n

In my next 3 blog posts I will cover websites and accessibility from a role-based standpoint: Web designers, web developers and web editors. This first contribution is meant for web designers, and gives concrete tips on how to create an accessible web design.

\n
\n

Include the remaining 20% of users

\n

Surveys show that up to 20% of web users are affected by accessibility issues when surfing the web. By following the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines you ensure that as many people as possible can use your website.  We've selected the following criteria as the most relevant for you as a web designer:

\n

Consistent design

\n

Some users may not be accustomed to using the Internet at all, and other users may have a disability that makes it hard to get an overview of a webpage or navigate a website. Therefore, it's important that the navigation is consistent across all your web pages, and global elements like menus and help facilities are in the same order across the site. It's also important that elements with the same function (such as icons and references) are ordered in the same way on every page ( Success criteria 3.2.3 and Success criteria 3.2.4).

\n

Navigation

\n

In order to make it easy for users to find information it's important to have more than one way of finding specific content on a web page. A user can find content on a page by navigating through the intended page hierarchy, but it should also be possible to find the page in another way through a sitemap, an index or a search function ( Success criteria 2.4.5).

\n

Headings

\n

When designing the look and feel and the architecture of a website, it's important to keep in mind that some users cannot get a visual overview of a web page. They have to do this structurally. Make sure pages are divided into logical sections each having a heading (coded as an <h> tag) describing the content, so that assistive technologies can render them as section headings ( Success criteria 1.3.1 and Success criteria 2.4.6).

\n

Use of color

\n

In order to make sure that all users are aware that an element on a web page has a certain function or status, it is important not to give information solely by the use of color. For users who cannot see colors, that information can be lost. An example of conveying information through colors could be to show links within a text by giving links a different color than the text. Supplement this with another non-color specific way of indicating the links (such as underline, a symbol etc.) ( Success criteria 1.4.1).

\n

In order for visually impaired users to be able to read all the text on web pages it is important that the color of the text and the color of the background are in sufficient contrast to each other. This can be ensured by conforming to the requirement of keeping a contrast ratio of 4.5:1 for regular text and 3:1 for large text. There are a number of tools available to quickly assist in measuring the contrast ratios ( Success criteria 1.4.3).

\n

Links

\n

When an element on a web page is to be a link or something clickable, it's important that the element text/description makes sense when read out of context. Part of this is ensured by the technical implementation but the design should consider using descriptive link texts also. Link texts such as: 'Read more,' 'here,' 'Click here,' and 'publication' are examples of poor link text if read out of their context ( Success criteria 2.4.4).

\n

Interactive elements

\n

When designing for interactive elements, i.e. content that the user can interact with, there should be a clear explanation of what is to be entered/chosen/checked. The design should make sure that when text fields, drop downs, check boxes and radio buttons are used, they have text connected to them describing their purpose ( Success criterion 2.4.6 and Success criterion 3.3.2).

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n

\n Awards\n

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n6/13/12 10:50 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

It's official: we're fun.

\n
\n\n
\n

It's always nice to hear that your coworkers enjoy working with you. A pat on the back or an 'attaboy for a job well done always goes a long way.  But if an 'attaboy makes us proud, having the colleagues' love published in a magazine makes our hearts swell.

\n

We're proud to announce that Siteimprove has been named one of the "Best 100 Companies to Work For" by Minnesota Business Magazine! The decision was based on an employee satisfaction survey, which MN Business Mag explains in their announcement blog post:

\n

"Beginning on February 15, 2012, independent research group, Gilmore Research, gathered information from employee satisfaction surveys over phone and mail. More than 5,700 individuals responded on behalf of hundreds of companies, and the winners were determined by employee scores."

\n

If you're looking for us in the list, we're under the "Small Companies" category :)

\n

We're especially proud of this award because it means the hard work we put into making the office fun and productive has been paying off.

\n

Our company culture

\n

 

\n

No performance review scores were harmed in the making of this photo

\n

 

\n

At Siteimprove, we're people first. We're holistically invested in each other because life outside of work is important, too.

\n

We value pride, passion and thoroughness, and strive to incorporate those core values into everything that we do. We're also an environmentally conscious corporation and a good neighbor to our communities, because sooner or later what goes around comes around.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8718690636:\n\n\n\n\n\nThe added bonus of ensuring web accessibility\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\nThe added bonus of ensuring web accessibility\n

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n5/2/12 11:19 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you looking to attract more visitors and retain happier users of your website? If so, then read on! By conforming with a number of accessibility criteria you can not only optimize the accessibility of your website, but also ensure good usability and increased visibility in search engines (SEO).

\n
\n\n

Allow me to give you some examples:

\n

1. Use Headings

\n

The accessibility guidelines prescribe the use of headings (H1, H2… H6) to divide web page content into logical sections, this will also help your ranking in search engines. Visually impaired users can get an overview of a web page and its sections by using the headings that a screen reader brings out. The search engines do the same.

\n

2. Remember alternative descriptions with images

\n

Additionally, the search engines prefer images that have good alternative descriptions. Having these alternative descriptions also helps visually impaired users of screen readers. A blind person cannot see an image and for this reason they need an alternative explanation giving the function of the image. A search engine is also 'blind' and cannot see an image but it can read an alternative text.

\n

3. Write meaningful link text 

\n

A number of criteria for accessibility cover the subject of writing sensible link texts and not just link texts reading 'click here', 'read more' etc. This also helps search engines. If you write a text that says something meaningful about the link destination, both assistive technologies and search engines can make good use of it.

\n

4. Help with input 

\n

When users are to fill out form fields on a web page an accessibility requirement is that you let the user know what is to be filled out, what is mandatory to fill out and at the same time provide help for users who make errors in their entry by giving them tips for correction. This of course helps with the overall usability of your website.

\n

5. Remember validation 

\n

When the accessibility guidelines require that your web pages conform with the current standards for web content, for instance html 4.01 or xhtml 1.0, adhering to this guideline also helps assistive technologies to interpret your content. It helps to ensure platform independence with the effect of having your web pages work and look presentable in different browsers.

\n

6. Enhance user journey

\n

Having an uncluttered and homogeneous website with consistent navigation helps all users. At the same time it is a good idea to give users more than one way of finding web pages such as having a search function, a site map or an index on the website. These are defined accessibility requirements but it is also best practice for the user experience in general.

\n

These points are just a few of the areas where ensuring web accessibility optimizes your website in other areas at the same time. So before you abandon accessibility guidelines thinking they're a hassle, not important, or just for 'a few disabled users' think about the added bonus / side benefits that make your investment valuable for both you and your web users.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8718697136:\n\n\n\n\n\n13 Tips to Improve Your Website for Mobile Users and Disabled Users at the Same Time\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\n13 Tips to Improve Your Website for Mobile Users and Disabled Users at the Same Time\n

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n10/17/12 3:46 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Smart phone sales are exploding, and the desire to make websites accessible to all users on mobile platforms is also increasing. I’m going to give you some tips on how to create accessible web content in the best way.

\n
\n\n
\n

One of the main principles of accessibility optimization is to ensure platform independence, which ensures the website is usable on many different platforms. If you ensure that your website is conforming to the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines, you will find that your accessibility for mobile devices is ensured to a large extent as well.

\n

A number of principles are relevant when using best practices for web accessibility on mobile platforms. Here are 13 tips on how to fix the most common problems faced by mobile web users.

\n

Design

\n

1. Layout

\n

Design in a way that makes the website work when users can only see a small part of the screen at a time, when they are browsing with mobile units. Some disabled users use zooming software to help them read the page, which creates the same issues imposed by the small screen on many smart phones. Avoid a situation where the user has to scroll both vertically and horizontally, and avoid images that are larger than the screen.

\n

2. Use of color

\n

It is important to avoid creating features or giving information solely based on the user's ability to see colors. Some users are unable to see or differentiate between certain colors. It's also important to make sure the contrast between the background and the text is sufficiently high.

\n

Also, make sure to avoid giving instructions that are color-dependent. (A color-dependent way of giving instructions can be to write: "click on the green button" or "in the blue box to your right you will find more information". If these kinds of descriptions are used make sure to supplement them with a text reference also, such as: 'click on the green button labeled 'Send' or ''in the blue box to your right with the heading 'Events' you will find more information").

\n

Development

\n

3. Following standards

\n

Make sure to follow the standards on the format which you have chosen to publish in. Having clean, validated code helps to ensure that the content is shown in a consistent manner across different platforms and enabling assistive technologies to render content in a meaningful way to users.

\n

4. Order of content

\n

Make sure content is wrapped in a sensible way and that content makes sense from the document order and when linearized. This ensures the content order is meaningful regardless of how the user accesses it and how much CSS is supported by their device.

\n

Tables commonly don't work well on small screens. Consider if there is an alternative way to give tabular content.

\n

5. Navigation

\n

Make sure links and forms are navigable when tabbing through content.

\n

6. Plugins

\n

Avoid making it required for users to install plugins to be able to use content. There might be situations where these are not supported or do not work with certain types of assistive technologies a user might need.

\n

7. Sound and warnings

\n

Avoid giving warnings and other significant information by the use of sound, Some users are not able to hear this either because of a hearing impairment or because of a situation such as being in a location with background noise that makes it hard to hear.

\n

8. Entering data

\n

It may be difficult for some users to enter information by the use of the limited keyboard available on a mobile unit. Make sure to use radio buttons, check boxes and combo boxes when user input is needed. This way, users have to enter as little text as possible via the keyboard.

\n

When users are entering data, make sure to prompt them and help them when they make mistakes. Make sure to technically do this in a way that ensures that it works with voice over and the likes.

\n

9. Page titles

\n

Give each web page a meaningful, short descriptive title. This helps users to ensure that they are on the right page.

\n

Communications

\n

10. Links

\n

Make sure all links have a text or a description that makes sense also when read out of context. Some users navigate between links and for this reason they are dependent on the link text indicating what the link is for.

\n

11. Words and sentences

\n

Avoid complicated words and long sentences. These are not very well suited to mobile units and they complicate things unnecessarily for people with reading difficulties.

\n

12. Subtitles

\n

Multimedia content such as video and sound must be provided with subtitles. In this way people who cannot hear and people with lots of background noise will still be able to understand the content.

\n

13. Images and alternatives

\n

Make sure that when content is non-text, such as images, it has a text alternative. This way users who cannot see and users who have disabled images on their mobile devices can still use the content. Avoid using CSS image replacement and make sure not to use images of text.

\n

More information

\n

W3C has developed a set of documents describing how to best create web content for mobile units and apps for mobile units. You can also read more on how these are connected to the web content accessibility guidelines. They are connected from to different starting points: If you would like to learn more about web accessibility on mobile units or if your starting point is web accessibility and you need to learn more on mobile units.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8689813666:\n\n\n\n\n\n6 Ways to Catch Website Issues Before They're a Problem\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n6 Ways to Catch Website Issues Before They're a Problem\n

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/28/14 9:04 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

Issues with your website can be absolutely devastating. Despite any of the marketing momentum or client base that you've built up, you may find your traffic ranking and following drastically tanking due to website errors. Lag, bad links, a lack of accessibility and even outdated content can quickly damage a website's SEO and lose the faith of its readership. Luckily, there are some ways you can avoid these issues before they even become a problem.

\n

\n
\n
\n

1. Define roles and responsibilities among your team.

\n

One of the best ways to catch website issues is to ensure that they never occur in the first place. Having clearly set roles and responsibilities throughout your development team is the perfect way to ensure that everything is taken care of from start to finish. This removes any ambiguity regarding who is responsible for the finished project at the end, and ensures that no one makes changes to certain parts of the project after it has been completed.

\n

Good communication is essential for a solid development team, but good software is also important. Project management software will be the foundation upon which your development team builds. You need not only a capable software suite but also well-defined protocols regarding communication, when it should be done and where it should be done. As an example, consistent note-taking within the project management software itself can greatly sidestep any issues and stopping points.

\n

2. Perform regular inventories of web content.

\n

Many people don't consider "outdated content" to be a website issue, but today, it's a serious one. Outdated content or content that is flawed can quickly plummet your website ranking, leading to as many problems overall as you would have had if your website didn't work at all. You should regularly inventory your web content to ensure that it is all current and that it is all working.

\n

Links, in particular, may degrade over time. Sending people to an incorrect web address is terrible, and loading an image that no longer exists is even worse; it looks unprofessional, distracts them and again, sends your web ranking tumbling downwards. An automated system is the best solution for those that want to regularly inventory their web content: it can complete the inventory behind the scenes on a regular basis.

\n

3. Use automation to your benefit.

\n

No one is perfect. Even your developers and your website testers may miss something from time to time, and that is why automated error discovery is so incredibly important. Automated website checking can comb every corner of your website thoroughly and can discover things that others might miss, such as pages that are no longer in compliance with current web standards. These are things that aren't necessarily visible to the human eye, but will be visible to search engines.

\n

4. Conduct speed and stress tests.

\n

Many of the issues that occur with a website won't occur until it is actually pushed to the limit. You may not realize that your server will break under the strain of high traffic, or that your current website is utilizing more memory and processing time than is really viable. Conducting speed and stress tests are the only way to replicate an actual operating environment and ensure that things don't go wrong when you least expect it.

\n

5. Anticipate the things that can go wrong.

\n

Regardless of how much error checking you do, there are things that might go wrong. Anticipating these problems and reacting to them in advance is how you can minimize the damage. Having custom error pages to ensure that clients don't get lost on your site is a fantastic way to make sure that they'll stay on the site should the worst happen.

\n

You should also have contingency plans in place for if the website does go down, and a clear system of responsibilities that tells your team who is responsible for acting if an emergency does occur.

\n

6. Pay attention to your analytics.

\n

Occasionally, something could go wrong and you might have no idea. There are things that could go wrong on your website that might not be noticeable, and paying attention to your analytic data is a fantastic way to ensure that you catch these issues before they get any worse. Your statistics can show you tremendous volumes of information if you let it.

\n

Your bounce rate, as well as the average time your visitors spend on your website, will be able to tell you quite a lot. If these indicators suddenly change, there could be a problem that you don't know about, such as a server load increase that's causing pages to lag.

\n

Maintaining a website can seem like a tremendous chore, but there are many ways that you can make it easier on both yourself and your team. An all-in-one solution like Siteimprove can be used to catch issues before they become a problem. Siteimprove can crawl your website on a regular basis to ensure the fidelity of links, the accessibility of the site and the site's overall quality. It can even provide valuable analytics and alert your entire team should something go wrong.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n

\nTell users about your cookies\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMie Elmkvist Jensen\n

\n

\n5/23/12 11:04 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Online privacy is a global hot-button, with lawmakers pressuring organizations to more tightly regulate the information they gather from visitors. The European Union recently enacted legislation dubbed the "cookie directive" has organizations scrambling to make their websites compliant. Many organizations in the US may not realize that they need to comply with these rules if they intend to operate a website in the EU. For those of you who don't run multiple sites, these simple tips may give you a head start preparing for future US legislation.

\n
\n\n
\n

Maybe it's time for a spring cleaning?

\n

Criticism of the new EU cookie directive has been extensive and we have yet to see any brilliant solutions proposed. However, it seems that these rules will not go away, so why not be a little creative and take the opportunity to get some spring cleaning done on your websites?  In May 2011, an EU directive about cookies came into effect and is currently being implemented in the different member countries.  There has been some debate and confusion about how to comply with the rules. Even though this is a European directive, all websites doing business in Europe should comply, and it might be useful for your users at the same time.

One purpose of the rules is to increase self-regulation in this area, which means that it is up to each website to form their own solution ensuring compliance. Therefore, it is surprising that we are yet to see good examples of solutions in a world where these kinds of cases are instantly turned into a business case.

\n

What should I do?

\n

There are 4 main points that you should be aware of in terms of complying with the regulations. The rules apply to all websites.

\n
    \n
  1. Anyone who has a website that uses cookies should inform their visitors thereof.
    2. \n
  2. Information must be easily accessible and clear, using language that the end user will understand so that every user will be adequately informed.
    3. \n
  3. The user should be informed about the purpose of the website's cookies and who stores their data.
    4. \n
  4. Lastly, it is also the website owner's responsibility to obtain consent from the user. This aspect is crucial when wanting to comply with the regulation.
    5. \n
\n


You should be aware that the consent of the user must be obtained before any cookies are set. You must therefore ensure that no cookies are set at the moment when a user enters your website, but only after the user has accepted cookies. You should be able to control when cookies are set, however this might seem incomprehensible to many. The reason many people might find it difficult to meet this demand, is that they do not know exactly which cookies are set by their website. Maybe that's exactly why an audit and perhaps a spring cleaning are needed.

\n

Why should I do it?

\n

The quick answer is; 'because the regulation says so,' but let's have a look at the purpose of the rules: Those visiting your website are informed about what happens. Additionally, visitors must have the option to opt out. When you put it this way, it's probably only a few who will oppose to the idea, because who doesn't support having the freedom to choose?

However, there are still some who may ignore the rule, because they fear that many will opt out, which will make their web analytics less exact. They believe that many will opt out "because they do not know what it is." Paradoxically, this answer brings us back to a part of the background for the rules, namely that information about cookies is needed. This will also help to demystify what cookies are not.

A small survey carried out by 40 people via SurveyMonkey indicates that the users who opt out are also those who do not know what a cookie is; thus indicating those who are afraid of what effect the use of cookies has.

First and foremost, it turns out that more than 1 in 3 people do not know what cookies are, despite the fact that 90% of them use the Internet on a daily basis for several purposes. At the same time an equal number of respondents said that they feel monitored and are afraid that the cookies were used for the purpose of raising prices. With this in mind one can easily argue that if the website owner has a legal and beneficial purpose with cookies, namely to make the user experience better, it's a good idea to share that message!

\n

How can I use it?

\n

Since the rules came into effect, they have been met with some dissatisfaction. Many believe that it is a measure potentially impairing their web analytics. This is one way of looking at things, but looking at it from a different point of view one might realize the possibilities.

\n

Since a large part of using cookies is to gather knowledge, which ultimately makes the website a better place for the user, there appears to be no reason not to tell the user about it.

\n

Cookies seen through branding glasses

\n

Of course there are website owners who use this technology for bad purposes, but if you don't, there is probably nothing to fear. Maybe it's a bit far-fetched, but looking at this through branding glasses, it is only a good thing that the web team will actually take the time to see how they can make the user experience better. So why not tell the users that their visit is making the web team wiser and the website better?

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

Happy Clients

\n

Here's what they have to say about us

\n
\n
    \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    As a one-person marketing team, Siteimprove helps me work smarter, not harder. The easy interface and daily reports make it easy to find website errors before customers do. Don’t overlook the opportunity to have a web quality control source so easily available to you!

    \n
    \nMarketing Director at Senn Delaney Leadership Consulting Group, LLC.
    \n
    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    The Web Governance Suite is one of our best investments. The quality assurance tool enabled us to clean up a plethora of content on our website, as well as gives us the ability to proactively monitor new material. As someone who deals with a magnitude of software and apps, I can truly appreciate when something comes along that actually makes my life easier.

    \n
    \nManager of Marketing Technology at Blank Rome LLP.
    \n
    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    Siteimprove Analytics is filled with useful features like single page tracking, PDF, and behavior tracking. The page inventory and individual page analytics assists with my ROT (Redundant, Outdated or Trivial) assessments. Siteimprove Analytics is an invaluable tool for ensuring we continue to provide our users with content that best meets their needs.

    \n
    \nWeb Architect at City of Huron
    \n
    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    We've seen a 56% increase in average time spent on our website. Quality Assurance makes finding and fixing problem areas on our site much more manageable - we couldn't maintain our site so responsibly without it.

    \n
    \nLead Web Developer at BOSCH Security Systems
    \n
    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    Siteimprove gives us peace of mind managing a site with many content contributors. With so many moving parts, mistakes have a way of finding their way onto a website regardless of the safeguards in our CMS, and Siteimprove makes it easy and efficient to catch them when they happen. Siteimprove has saved countless hours and grey hairs since we began using them in 2008.

    \n
    \nTechnology / Web Coordinator at City of St. Louis Park
    \n
    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    Siteimprove Quality Assurance, quite simply put is indispensable. I manage a higher ed website with thousands of pages and since incorporating Siteimprove into our maintenance schedule I have confidence that users will not find broken links or spelling errors, both which erode our credibility as an institution of higher learning. Whether a broken link is the result of a change from an external site we are linked to or a domino effect from something we have done elsewhere on the site, Siteimprove alerts us to the problem and we can address the issue quickly. The ability to segment and share the reports enables those closest to specific content to be involved in a productive and expedient way.

    \n
    \nAssistant Director of Communications at Cornell University
    \n
    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    We love Siteimprove Response! It revealed that our internet service was at 92-93% uptime, rather than our service provider’s 99% guarantee. We were able to take the data from Response and present it to our Internet Service Provider, who then dramatically improved our service.

    \n
    \nSystems Analyst at Tampa International Airport
    \n
    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    Our municipality and municipal officers have a passion for inclusive environments and removing barriers, and Siteimprove Accessibility helps us quickly determine exactly how to make that a reality. The ability to log in from any computer and for the product to connect directly to our web content management system saves us a bundle of time, and the way it breaks down web accessibility errors and notifications by priority compliance levels keeps our editors from getting overwhelmed.

    \n
    \nCoordinator of Customer Service at Town of Huntsville
    \n
    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    Siteimprove SEO breaks down search engine optimization into an easy-to-understand format that allows us to interpret our strengths and weaknesses clearly and efficiently. We’ve been able to utilize this information to modify our website to improve our search rankings and easily explain our progress to the firm’s business development committee with concise monthly reports provided by Siteimprove. I strongly recommend Siteimprove SEO.

    \n
    \nMarketing Coordinator at Larkin Hoffman
    \n
    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    Every company with a large website should use Quality Assurance from Siteimprove. Nowadays, your website is your brick and mortar, so reputable content and accurate information is key to any brand. Siteimprove will streamline the process and easily point out any errors or inconsistencies.

    \n
    \nInternet Specialist at Saint Joseph Mercy Health System
    \n
    \n
    \n
    • \n
\n

    \n

    \nRead\n

    BY Star Bazella

    2. Oct 2014

    \n
    \n
    • \n

    \n

    Latest Blog Post: 3 Tips For Creating An Effective Website Content Calendar

    \n

    With the demand for consistent, high-quality web content growing on a daily basis, creating a Content Calendar is the best way to coordinate and organize your content marketing efforts and ensure that your brand remains top of mind with your core audience.

    \n

    Content Calendars will vary from organization to organization, but by compiling all of your goals, assets, and ideas in a single document, you’ll be able to piece together what can turn into an otherwise unruly and chaotic puzzle.

    \n

    Ready? Set? Go.

    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n

    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    On-Demand Webinar: The Foundations of a Website Redesign

    \n

    A website redesign isn’t simply a chance to give your website a fresh look. It also gives you an opportunity to reorganize the way your site is structured and how your content is presented in order to support your business objectives. In this 30 minute webinar, we will recap how to prepare for a website redesign, learn how to set the foundation, and frame the website.

    \n

    You’ll walk away from this on-demand webinar with a solid understanding on how to outline and organize your site structure and how to map out primary, secondary, and tertiary content for your website redesign.

    \n

    \n

    \n

    eBook: Web Analytics Where to Begin

    \n

    People love the Internet. A lot. In fact, 92% of online adults rely on search engines when looking for information. Web analytics provide you with a better understanding of how visitors are finding your website, how they interact with it, and how effectively your website is contributing to your business goals.

    \n

    Download this complimentary web analytics eBook and gain a better understanding of what web analytics are and how you can use them to achieve your business goals.

Recent Posts

\n

Top 5 SEO and Accessibility Overlaps

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n1/16/13 10:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Did you know that guidelines and best practices for SEO and web accessibility have many overlaps, and that with a little consideration you can kill two birds with one stone? We give you our top five areas that make your website more searchable and at the same time accessible for more users.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Governance from an SEO Point of View

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n10/31/12 3:33 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

There are a lot of similarities between Search Engine Optimization (SEO) today and the “dot-com bubble” of the 1990s: Back then people were buying websites they didn’t really understand or have a plan to use, simply because everyone else had one.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

9 Ways to Keep Your Search Rankings During a Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n9/12/12 4:28 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Getting a new website can be like walking into a minefield in terms of search engine optimization. Worst case scenario, you could lose all your search engine rankings and will have to start from scratch. Luckily, this doesn’t have to happen - as long as you do the transition the right way.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n

\n

Search Engine Optimization (SEO) and Mobile Websites

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n8/1/12 4:55 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Last week's blog post was about the need for mobile websites. And if your website isn't already mobile friendly, you're probably thinking of doing something about it. However, not all mobile websites are particularly search engine friendly, so in this blog post we will briefly present 3 options to help you make the right decisions on how to go about building your mobile website.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

On page optimization post panda: 3 tips to future-proof your website

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n7/18/12 5:24 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Google regularly updates the algorithm that calculates a page's relevance to a given search. Last year in February came the much debated panda update, which has since been updated many times, even as recently as April of this year. Having just returned from the Search Marketing Expo in London, we have lots of good ideas on how to ensure that the content on your website meets the new requirements.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Four good ideas on how to find the right keywords

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n6/20/12 10:48 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Keywords are at the very heart of search engine optimization and finding the right keywords can make or break your SEO success. It is therefore very important to find the right keywords to target. It is impossible to optimize your website for all interesting keywords, so you will want to start out with the most important ones. Here, we will give you four good ideas on how to find the right keywords.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8718668226:\n\n\n\n\n\nGetting Started With Web Analytics\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n

\nGetting Started With Web Analytics\n

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/9/13 10:38 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In this post, you'll find a brief walkthrough of how to begin using the basic features of an analytics program. We will be using Siteimprove Analytics as our example, however the suggestions made should carry over to any program.

\n
\n\n
\n

The Dashboard

\n

The dashboard is the central hub of any web analytics program, and displays summaries of your most important data all in one place.  Here's what the dashboard looks like in Siteimprove Analytics:

\n

 

\n

1. Filters

\n

Filters tailor all the data you see displayed in the program.  They can be customized to filter out traffic from within your organization, filter by times and dates, or even filter by where visitors came from.

\n

2. Unique Visitors

\n

The number of different visitors to your website in the selected period. If someone visits your site, leaves and then comes back it will only count as one unique visit.
Important things to note: this doesn't necessarily reflect an accurate picture of the number of people who visited, because most people today have multiple devices (computers, tablets, smartphones). For example: if someone visits your website from their work computer during the workday, and then later visits your website again from their personal laptop at home, there's no way for your analytics program to know that this is in fact the same person using different devices.  So "Unique Visitors" is really more a measurement of the number of devices that have visited your website. There are other ways that this number might be affected by visitor behavior like clearing their browser's cookies, but for the purpose of brevity we won't get into that here.

\n

3. Visits

\n

This is the total number of times that anyone visited your site, whether it was for the first time or the hundredth time. If someone visits your site, leaves and then comes back again, it will count as two visits.
Important things to note: there is a timeout limit of 30 minutes on each visit. If someone views your website and then leaves it up on their computer while they go watch TV for a while, when they come back and view another page, it will show up as a second visit.

\n

4. Page Views

\n

A count of how many times a page or page group has been viewed in the selected time period. If a visitor hits your homepage, that's one page view. If they then go on to your "About Us" section, that's a another page view. 

\n

5. Bounce Rate

\n

The bounce rate is calculated by dividing the number of single-page visits (in which a visitor only viewed one page before exiting the website) by the total number of visits by the number of visits.
While it has become a staple of most analytics program dashboards, the Bounce Rate really isn't the best way for beginners to measure their website's performance.
Say your website has a bounce rate of 65%, what does that tell you? Are visitors bouncing because they found what they wanted, or because they didn't find what they wanted?  If people commonly visit your homepage to find hours of operation, your address, phone number, etc. they will most likely bounce if they find what they're looking for on your page (many sites have this information in the footer). So in that case, your analytics program reports a bounce even though your users found exactly what they were looking for.

\n

6. Most Popular Pages

\n

Your website's most popular pages are listed in order of page views and bounce rate.  These web pages are typically the ones that are the closest to your home page, requiring the fewest clicks to get there.  However, if you see pages deep in your website at the top of this list, you may want to consider moving them closer to the homepage to make them easier to find. To see the full list of pages in order of popularity, click the "View more" button.

\n

7. Referrers

\n

This graph displays the different types of ways people are finding your website online. As you can see in the screenshot above, "Direct Traffic" usually makes up the majority of your referrals. "Direct Traffic" refers to people who directly typed your URL into their browser, rather than clicking a link or doing a search.

\n

"Search Engines" is fairly self-explanatory, showing how many of your website's visitors found you through searches on Google, Bing, Yahoo!, etc.

\n

"External Referrers" shows people who found your website by clicking a link somewhere else on the internet.  If Jimbo's Jumbo Texas Shrimp blog posts a link to your website telling his readers that you sell the best shrimp cocktail sauce, anyone who follows that link to your website will show up under your "External Referrers" category.

\n

8. External Search Terms

\n

Since search engines make up a sizeable chunk of total website traffic on most websites, it's valuable to see which searches people are using to find you. Usually the top search terms are all variations of your company or product name, which isn't all that helpful.  However in Siteimprove Analytics, you can filter out all variations of your company, product or any other criteria you like to help you focus on what's really important.

\n

Have questions about analytics?  Leave a comment below and our Analytics expert will get back to you ASAP!

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

The Foundations of a Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nStar Bazella\n

\n

\n8/19/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Embarking on a website redesign is no small undertaking. It will require a substantial amount of strategy, organization, and company soul-searching. Not only will you need to ask difficult questions, but you’ll need to provide answers that satisfy every major stakeholder. This prospect alone is enough to deter some organizations from pressing forward, but there are steps you can take in order to not only streamline your redesign project, but ensure that everyone’s needs are met.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Cognitive Disabilities and Website Accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n8/12/14 9:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

While sight and hearing disabilities are the most talked-about when it comes to website accessibility, cognitive disabilities actually represent the largest number of computer users with disabilities according to the National Center on Disability and Access to Education.

\n

So, why aren’t we more aware of cognitive disabilities? Well, because these types of disabilities contain a wide range of nuanced conditions and an even wider range of severity, so it’s difficult to present a comprehensive set of standards to which web developers should comply. 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Higher Education & The Web: Reaching Your Audience

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/7/14 10:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Finding the right medium for communicating with the most tech-savvy generations can be difficult. With the abundance of devices, platforms, and channels available to students these days, universities and colleges are forced to make difficult choices. Do they focus their attention on a select number of channels, or do they try to spread their efforts across as many as possible in the hopes of reaching the largest audience possible? There may not be a single right answer for every institution, but recent trends should help make finding those answers easier.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Using Web Analytics To Improve Your Content

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/5/14 11:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

So. You’ve got a website and it’s super swanky, what with all the bright colors, pretty designs, and such. It’s also probably filled with content that you’ve spent hours creating, cultivating, and curating. But is that content any good? I mean really, how do you know? Of course YOU think it’s good, you wrote it. No offense, but you don’t matter. If your audience doesn’t think your content is relevant or helpful, then you’re just wasting words. But people don’t always say what they mean or mean what they say, so how can you truly tell if your content is resonating with your audience? Analytics.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Governance Ask Us Anything Preview #2

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/29/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

As our panel of experts are busy answering the brain-busting questions submitted for our Ask Us Anything, we thought we'd share a sneak peek at the wisdom of our friend and Web Governance expert, Shane Diffily.

\n

You can download the full Ask Us Anything recording here.

\n

OK, I know. "Stop talking and give us the goods." 

\n

 

\n

 

\n

 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Web Governance Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/22/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Every organization has different goals for their online presence, a unique team managing that presence, and a distinct process for achieving their goals. What I’m trying to say, is that there’s no golden ticket, silver bullet, or metaphor in the world that will solve every organization’s web governance needs. However, there are plenty of ways to get your web governance endeavors started off on the right (or left) foot.

\n

Whether you’re just getting your organization’s web governance strategy in place, or need to get yours back to basics, here are a few areas to focus on.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Semantic Markup and Web Accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n7/17/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Web Content Accessibility Guideline 1.3, “Adaptable” is defined as: Creating content that can be presented in different ways (for example simpler layout) without losing information or structure. 

\n

HTML was originally designed to deliver documents with a structure that represented the importance and order of information. The creators of HTML were actually scientists who wanted a way to share technical documents. They didn’t really care about the visual look of the document as viewed on a screen—it just needed to correctly convey the information.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Ask Us Anything Preview

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/15/14 12:48 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

We're in a giving mood today, so we thought we'd share a quick preview of what you can expect to learn from our upcoming Ask Us Anything session.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How To Quickly Clean Up Disorganized Web Content

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n7/8/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

\n
\n

If you’re feeling overwhelmed by the prospect of cleaning up your website content, the suggestion to “get an overview of your content” may sound glib and unhelpful, but it really doesn’t need to be more complicated than that.

\n
\n

There are plenty of tools available to assist you in putting together an overview, so there’s no reason to ever waste your time manually creating a website inventory.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

5 Reasons Why Your Website Content Isn’t Influencing Readers

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/1/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Humanizing the digital world is no simple task. Thanks to the rapid advances in technology, the expansion of social media, and the ever growing influence of the Internet, consumers are growing more and more savvy by the day. They also have more choices than ever before, which means you have more competition than ever before. So the question becomes, how to distance yourself from competitors and convince consumers that your product/service/organization is the best option for them?

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

  • Knowledge
    • \n
  • About
    • \n

\n

Do a Winter Checkup on Your Internal Search

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n12/27/12 2:43 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

With holidays and winter weather approaching, it’s time to make sure that your internal search engine is ready for specific winter topics.

\n
\n
\n

Winter search topics

\n

You might think that "Christmas" and "snow" are the typical topics to optimize for, and it does make sense to make sure that the most relevant pages of your website come up at the top of your searches for these terms. However, the search terms that are being searched for most often during the holiday season are related to opening hours.

\n

In most organizations, opening hours change during holidays, and we typically see a spike in searches for hours of operation during December and January. Users also search for information about services that may have a change in schedule, like garbage collection.

\n

Preparing for search term synonyms

\n

Forgetting to optimize for synonyms of relevant words is a common mistake. Make sure that you catch all versions of the search terms being used. If you're working to optimize searches for garbage collection, appropriate synonyms of 'garbage' might include:

\n
    \n
  • Trash
    • \n
  • Refuse
    • \n
  • Waste
    • \n
  • Bin
    • \n
  • Recycling
    • \n
  • Collection
    • \n
\n

Additionally, opening hours during the holiday period should be searchable for all offices in your organization. If your organization provides services such as a library or a swimming pool then make sure that opening hours for these amenities during the holiday period are searchable too.

\n

Recycle search term statistics from last winter

\n

If you're looking to find specific search terms to optimize your internal search for, I recommend checking your analytics from last year. By looking at which search terms were searched for in December/January last year, you'll get a good idea for where to start this year.

\n

Share your experiences with us!

\n

Do you check and update your internal search?  We'd love to hear your experiences in the comments below. 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Get a head start by quality assuring your development site

\n

\nPosted by\nCamilla Simonsen\n

\n

\n12/19/12 2:49 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Many of our customers launched new websites in 2012, and took advantage of running our Quality Assurance and Accessibility checks on the development website. Finding and fixing errors on their website prior to launching is helpful in it's own right, but allowing the web developers early access to the tools has proven to be invaluable.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Web Designer's Guide on How to Create Accessible GUIs

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n12/12/12 2:58 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As a web designer, several accessibility criteria are especially important to help you ensure as many users as possible can use your web application.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8689771356:\n\n\n\n\n\nWhy Do My Documents Need To Be Accessible?\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog
