\n
\n
\n

\nWhy Do My Documents Need To Be Accessible?\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/10/14 11:03 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Admit it: “PDFs” aren’t usually the first thing that come to mind when you think about website accessibility. They probably should be. PDFs are nearly ubiquitous as a “final” document type on the web, and hosted PDFs are often the only location certain content is made available – especially for educators, the healthcare industry, and government offices. When they aren’t accessible, that information simply isn’t available to users with disabilities.

\n
\n

The lack of accessibility of online documents exposes website owners to the same risks as inaccessible web pages. Although we could address many different online documents such as Word, Excel, and PowerPoint, our focus will be on the predominant format, PDF (Portable Document Format).

\n

Q: What defines an Accessible Document?

\n

A: A document is considered accessible if all users, with or without disabilities, can read and understand all the information it contains.  Every user should be able to:

\n
    \n
  • Understand the document’s structure
    • \n
  • Read and understand the document’s contents, including text and images
    • \n
  • Understand and navigate sections such as tables
    • \n
  • Interact with any forms
    • \n
\n

Assistive technology is only as good as the information you provide to it. If you don’t provide good instructions, the technology isn’t able to do its job. Providing accessible instructions (tagged documents) ensures that assistive technology can accomplish its purpose. Remember that there are also different levels of accessibility—not accessible, partly accessible, and fully accessible. How you build your documents will determine these levels.

\n

Q: What Are the Document’s Accessibility Standards?

\n

A: It’s important to use the most relevant standard for any given technology, and online documents are no different. Here is how these different standards affect online documents:

\n

WCAG 2.0

\n

WCAG 2.0 applies to web content. Although PDF is not recognized by the W3C as a standard web format, PDF use on websites is addressed by 23 different WCAG PDF Techniques including:

\n
    \n
  • PDF1: Applying text alternatives to images (Success Criterion 1.1.1, Non-text content)
    • \n
  • PDF3: Ensuring correct tab and reading order in PDF documents (Success Criterion 1.3.2, Meaningful Sequence)
    • \n
  • PDF9: Providing headings (Success Criterion 1.3.1, Info and Relationships)
    • \n
  • PDF11: Providing links and link text (Success Criterion 1.3.1, Info and Relationships)
    • \n
  • PDF16: Setting the default language (Success Criterion 3.1.1, Language of Page)
    • \n
  • PDF21: Using List tags for lists in PDF documents (Success Criterion 1.3.1, Info and Relationships)
    • \n
\n

The PDF techniques will be covered in detail in a future blog post. In the mean time, which standard is considered the formal document standard for PDF files?

\n

PDF/UA (ISO 14289)

\n

PDF/UA is not a different file format, but a technique to implement the PDF format. The reason for PDF/UA (ISO 14289) is to describe how to create electronic documents in the PDF format in a way that allows the file to be accessible. The accessibility is dependent on semantic information in a document. Semantic information may also include additional metadata, like alternative text for images.

\n

Matterhorn Protocol

\n

To promote use of PDF/UA, the PDF Association’s PDF/UA Competence Center created the Matterhorn Protocol. The Matterhorn Protocol is a group of 31 checkpoints that includes 136 failure points corresponding to PDF/UA’s file format requirements.

\n

Just because a document passes PDF/UA compliance doesn’t mean it will pass the WCAG, and organizations shouldn’t treat PDF/UA as a WCAG replacement, but utilize both standards.

\n

Q: How Do Search Engines Handle PDFs?

\n

A: In the past search engines were not able to index PDF content, but that’s no longer the case; search engine technology is now able to gather much of the information provided in a document. The difference between web pages and PDF pages is that web pages are optimized for search engines. Many PDFs contain detailed information, and search engines love that detailed information. Properly tagged PDFs will enhance the indexing of the document, and make that detailed information much more valuable.

\n

Q: When Should I Use PDF files?

\n

Appropriate Uses of PDF Files

\n
    \n
  • Secure documents
    • \n
  • Downloadable documents
    • \n
  • Print documents that need to keep formatting
    • \n
  • Documents that provide more detail
    • \n
  • Interactive forms
    • \n
  • Low usage documents (large documents, archives)
    • \n
\n

Remember these insights:

\n
    \n
  • HTML achieves accessibility better than PDF
    • \n
  • Most PDFs on the web should be HTML
    • \n
  • Many websites have a print to PDF feature
    • \n
  • Some documents (Word, Excel, etc.), should be PDFs
    • \n
\n

Who is responsible for making the PDF accessible?

\n

Training

\n

Document content producers are usually different from your Web content producers. You will need to modify your training accordingly. Train producers on the appropriate techniques to save tagged PDFs.

\n

Templates

\n

Provide template files that meet both accessibility and branding guidelines. Move forward with new documents—make them accessible. Don’t try and convert all of your old files right away, convert them on an as-needed basis.

\n

Remediation

\n

Once you have created accessible templates for distribution, think about how you will update existing documents. Here are a few things to consider:

\n
    \n
  • Will you be providing accessible documents on an “as needed” basis?
    • \n
  • How often do you need to provide an accessible document?
    • \n
  • What is your turn-around time for providing an accessible document?
    • \n
  • Do you need to engage an outside provider to assist with document remediation?
    • \n
\n

Q: Where Do I Start?

\n

A: We’re offering a free webinar on getting started with document accessibility. The webinar is a valuable way to understand why your documents need to be accessible. We’ll discuss:

\n
    \n
  • What is an Accessible Document?
    • \n
  • Accessible Document Standards
    • \n
  • PDFs and Search Engines
    • \n
  • When to provide PDFs online
    • \n
  • Who is responsible for PDF accessibility?
    • \n
\n

We will then follow up with webinars on creating accessible documents in Word and InDesign.

\n

Sign up for our webinar, “Why Making PDF Accessible Documents is Important” here.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
We are here to answer any questions you may have about our web governance tools and solutions. Don’t hesitate to get in contact with us. Drop us a line.

How to figure out which How-To’s to write

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n3/17/13 3:01 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

How-To’s are great. They provide answers to your customers’ questions, but they're also a great opportunity to get some relevant targeted content on your website and boost your SEO efforts. But how do you know which How-To’s to write?

\n
\nRead More\n

Simple, yet lethal SEO no-no's

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n2/19/13 3:07 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

“A website is like an island resort. It serves no purpose if no one can find it” Dr. Clinton Cimring, Trademarker of the acronym S.E.O

\n
\n
\n

While most of us focus a lot of our time and money on improving our SEO, it's often the basics that are our undoing. With that in mind, we've come up with a list of common elementary mistakes that people make time and time again. And remember if your SEO efforts still aren't paying off then it may be time to consider investing in an SEO tool that helps take the mystery out of it.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Ensuring the last laugh isn't at your expense

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n2/6/13 4:16 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

We all enjoy having a good laugh at spelling mistakes, but the real challenge for those responsible for websites is ensuring that the last laugh isn’t at your expense.

\n
\n
\n

Maintaining your website's credibility is not easy, especially given that for most of us checking spelling mistakes, grammatical errors, and broken links is hardly our must-have hobby for 2013, however if you wish to ensure your website's success it is essential.

\n
\nRead More\n

Web Editors: Create Accessible Websites

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n1/29/13 9:38 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As a web editor you are responsible for the content you publish on the website and it’s accessibility. Do you know how to support accessibility when you write texts and add images and links on a web page?

\n
\n
\n

This is the final blog post in a series of 3 that cover websites and accessibility with a role-based approach. This post is meant for web editors. The previous was intended for web designers and for web developers. I will give concrete tips on how to create an accessible web site.

\n
\nRead More\n

\n

    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

It may be one thing to write blog posts about Web Governance, but using it in your day-to-day work is a completely different ball game. In this blog post I’ll show how we’ve tried to apply Web Governance at Siteimprove, and hopefully you’ll learn from our challenges.

\n
\nRead More\n

Top 5 SEO and Accessibility Overlaps

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n1/16/13 10:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Did you know that guidelines and best practices for SEO and web accessibility have many overlaps, and that with a little consideration you can kill two birds with one stone? We give you our top five areas that make your website more searchable and at the same time accessible for more users.

\n
\n

\n

Web Developers: Create an Accessible Website

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n1/2/13 2:35 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you developing your website for many types of users, or are you primarily developing for people who access websites in much the same way as you do? Do you know how dyslexic users, people who are colorblind, people with impairments and others navigate the web?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Do a Winter Checkup on Your Internal Search

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n12/27/12 2:43 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

With holidays and winter weather approaching, it’s time to make sure that your internal search engine is ready for specific winter topics.

\n
\n
\n

Winter search topics

\n

You might think that "Christmas" and "snow" are the typical topics to optimize for, and it does make sense to make sure that the most relevant pages of your website come up at the top of your searches for these terms. However, the search terms that are being searched for most often during the holiday season are related to opening hours.

\n

In most organizations, opening hours change during holidays, and we typically see a spike in searches for hours of operation during December and January. Users also search for information about services that may have a change in schedule, like garbage collection.

\n

Preparing for search term synonyms

\n

Forgetting to optimize for synonyms of relevant words is a common mistake. Make sure that you catch all versions of the search terms being used. If you're working to optimize searches for garbage collection, appropriate synonyms of 'garbage' might include:

\n
    \n
  • Trash
    • \n
  • Refuse
    • \n
  • Waste
    • \n
  • Bin
    • \n
  • Recycling
    • \n
  • Collection
    • \n
\n

Additionally, opening hours during the holiday period should be searchable for all offices in your organization. If your organization provides services such as a library or a swimming pool then make sure that opening hours for these amenities during the holiday period are searchable too.

\n

Recycle search term statistics from last winter

\n

If you're looking to find specific search terms to optimize your internal search for, I recommend checking your analytics from last year. By looking at which search terms were searched for in December/January last year, you'll get a good idea for where to start this year.

\n

Share your experiences with us!

\n

Do you check and update your internal search?  We'd love to hear your experiences in the comments below. 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Get a head start by quality assuring your development site

\n

\nPosted by\nCamilla Simonsen\n

\n

\n12/19/12 2:49 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n

    • \n

    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Many of our customers launched new websites in 2012, and took advantage of running our Quality Assurance and Accessibility checks on the development website. Finding and fixing errors on their website prior to launching is helpful in it's own right, but allowing the web developers early access to the tools has proven to be invaluable.

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8762552456:\n\n\n\n\n\nAdding Context To Your Web Analytics With Segmentation\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nAdding Context To Your Web Analytics With Segmentation\n

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n5/27/14 11:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

In the first three posts of this series we reviewed how to identify your KPIs and the merits of Event and Campaign tracking to give you the full picture of how people are arriving at, and interacting with, your website. Now it’s time to dive into two key tactics for analyzing your collected data to aid you in providing meaningful recommendations on how to improve the website going forward. Those tactics are segmentation and adding context.

\n\n

Segmentation is the practice of breaking your data down into common buckets, for example all people that arrived at your website via Facebook or all people that visited at least 3 pages.  Using segmentation allows you to target specific groups more effectively, and better allocate your marketing resources.

\n

Think about how difficult it is to look at all of the information gathered about your website at once and do anything useful with it. Pretty impossible, right? Now think about how much easier the task of deriving useful insights becomes when you can break the data down into manageable chunks that are relevant to a particular question you are trying to answer. Better? Good.

\n

There are some good rules to follow when applying segments to your data that can help you maximize your efforts.

\n

The first rule has to do with ensuring that you utilize at least one segment from each of these three categories; Acquisition, Behavior and Outcomes (Credit goes to Avinash Kaushik for these categories). Let’s define these categories and take a closer look at each.

\n

Acquisition

\n

Acquisition refers to all of the strategies you have used to attract people to your website. This includes things like SEO, email marketing, social media, etc. It’s a difficult task to determine which of these channels, and even options within these channels (which social network is right for us?!), deserves the limited resources you have in your organization.

\n

In order to fully understand and be able to apply acquisition segments, you need to make Campaign Tracking part of your digital measurement process.

\n

Behavior

\n

Behavior refers to all of the interactions that people can have while on your website, as well as the behavioral characteristics of visitors like time on site or pages per visit. This segment category is critical to understanding which particular behaviors lead people to ultimately take actions that benefits your organization.

\n

In order to fully understand and apply behavioral segments, you need to ensure you have Events set up if necessary.

\n

Outcomes

\n

Outcomes refer to actions taken by visitors on your website that benefit your business. This idea was covered in full through the first post in this series on identifying key performance indicators and micro conversions. Once those items are identified you can look at the segment of people who have completed those tasks and see if they were acquired differently or behaved differently than others.

\n

In order to fully understand and apply outcome segments, you need to ensure you have Events set up if necessary.

\n

The combination of these three segments will change how you look at your data. No longer will you simply be looking at piles of information with no idea why it is relevant. Instead, you will come out armed with information and questions that can help turn this mess of data into something useful.

\n

Say the purpose of your website is to generate leads through a contact form that you have, and you’d like to determine the most cost effective way for generating leads going forward.

\n

You’ve decided to test three different acquisition strategies over the course of the next month, which are: an email campaign, an Adwords campaign, and a Twitter campaign. At the end of the month you’ll need to apply those three Acquisition segments to your data along with the Outcomes segment of leads generated. By understanding which strategy generated the most leads, you can make better decisions on how to delegate your resources across the channels going forward.

\n

At the same time you’re also interested if there are particular behaviors on your website that lead to people filling out your form. By having the Outcomes segment activated, you can look for behavior trends like pages visited before completing the form, did people watch your most recent video before converting and other behavioral interactions like this to improve your chances for conversions going forward.

\n

To set up these segments in the Siteimprove tool you’ll need to use the Filters area. Here, you have several options on how you want to view your information. If I was interested in how people on our website behaved, and how many converted, that came from our email campaigns I would create the following filter:

\n

\n

I would now be able to look at all the information about people who arrived at the Siteimprove website by email:

\n

\n

So, I could check my Outcomes (signing up for a demo or subscribing to a newsletter) or I could look at other Behaviors (popular pages or white paper downloads). By reviewing this information, I can now understand what people who arrive at siteimprove.com by email are likely to do and then I can decide how to improve upon that based on our goals.

\n

You can see just how important it is to identify what to track on your website and ensure that you have the appropriate implementation in place if you want to get value from your data, but you can’t stop there. You also need to add Context to your data.  

\n

Context is that extra bit of information that helps the data make sense. It helps to further answer the question of “why?” when you are staring at a report. The hard part about context is that often times you won’t find it in your web analytics tool, you’ll find it when thinking about your organization as a whole.

\n

In the above screen capture, you can see the ramp up of visits to siteimprove.com via email. In looking at that picture one of the first questions I have is, “why so little traffic in April compared to May?” I’m not going to find the answer to that question in my analytics tool. I have to go talk with the Marketing Department here to find out about our emailing habits.

\n

There, I might find out that we really didn’t start doing email marketing until late March, or I may find out that we did not have Campaign Tracking appropriately set up. I may even find out that we changed the content in the emails that were being sent which led to an uptick in traffic. All of this context would be incredibly helpful to me if I were trying to analyze the effectiveness of our email campaigns in terms of our website.

\n

This is by no means easy work. It requires you to know what problem you’re trying to solve or question you’re trying to answer. Applying the appropriate segments to your data and understanding your organization well enough to find the appropriate context that will truly help the data make sense. Once you’ve gone through this process for all the questions that people are asking you about your website, you’ll be ready to put together a report that is much more than just basic data. It will be a report that adds value and contains your recommendations for action!

\n

\n \n \n

\n

 

\n

 

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8857869826:\n\n\n\n\n\nAsk Us Anything Preview\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\nAsk Us Anything Preview\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/15/14 12:48 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

We're in a giving mood today, so we thought we'd share a quick preview of what you can expect to learn from our upcoming Ask Us Anything session.

\n\n

For those who are just hearing about it, Ask Us Anything brought 5 of our resident Web Governance, Web Accessibility, and Content Marketing experts together in order to answer questions submitted by our customers.

\n

Below are some of the questions we weren't able to answer during the live recording, but you can download the full recording here.

\n

OK, now here's your free knowledge for the day:

\n

1. Can we pull reports in the Siteimprove tool for just our Admissions webpages and have them sent only to selected users, instead of everyone?

\n

 Heather Orfe - Technical Support and Training Manager

\n

"This setup is easily obtainable through the settings within the ‘Access & Reports’ portion of a user’s profile shown in the image below.

\n

\n

In this portion of the user setup, you can assign the user with access to the tool and QA reports – once you have these changes, you’ll then have additional options to provide the user access and reports to any group you currently have setup. Select the page group(s) the user is responsible for, then select ‘Group access only’ in the upper right corner.

\n

This parameter specifies the users’ settings to only the pages in the group(s) you’ve assigned them to. Without this distinction, a user would have access to the entire sites performance, with an option to manually select into their group."

\n

2. What are the most common accessibility concerns for web users?

\n

 Kevin Rydberg - Siteimprove Senior eAccessibility Consultant

\n

"A few of the questions I get regularly include, 'What are the requirements or regulations I need to follow?' and 'Where do I start?' One of the first things to consider is that accessible coding is a process, not a singular task. These coding practices need to become part of your daily workflow and in time, will feel like a natural part of the development process.

\n

The best places to start, in order to determine the requirements for your website's accessibility, are the WCAG website and Section 508 website, which outline some of the most common accessibility challenges, regulations, and how to address them.

\n

You can also read some of my Web Accessibility blogs for more specific details on how to make your website accessible for all users."

\n

3. I need to review analytics for a section of my website, but cannot use the Page Title or URL for Grouping, what do I do?

\n

 Steve Hennigs - Siteimprove Vice President of Customer Success

\n

"There is an option where Siteimprove can look for a unique piece of HTML on your page, for example if you have a BreadCrumb present, and use that to put common pages together in groups. This does require some interaction with the Siteimprove support team for the initial set up but once that is complete you are able to add groups through the Siteimprove UI.

\n

Just contact our support team and they'd be happy to help get you started."

\n

4. How do I identify if a website redesign is necessary?

\n

 Star Bazella - Siteimprove Director of Marketing

\n

"First, consider the business goal of your website. The design of your website must serve the right purpose, and help you achieve a clearly identified goal, or set of goals. Here are some questions you should answer to determine if a website redesign is necessary.

\n
    \n
  • Which areas of your site are performing well, underperforming, or failing completely? Basically, what problems or issues are you trying to fix with a new site?
    • \n
  • What do you want visitors to know about your company/organization?
    • \n
  • What do you want visitors to do when they visit the site?
    • \n
  • How can you attract visitors and convert them into leads?
    • \n
  • What does success of your website look like?
    • \n
\n

Remember that success does not mean the same thing for all pages or types of visitors. Consider how returning visitors might have different needs from new visitors, or how visitors from an email might have different needs than visitors from organic search. Think about the goals of individual pages and subdirectories, and how they might differ."

\n
\n

Download the full Ask Us Anything recording here. 

\n

 

\n

  \n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8944480926:\n\n\n\n\n\nOn-Demand Webinar: Cognitive Disabilities & Web Accessibility\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

On-Demand Webinar: Cognitive Disabilities & Web Accessibility

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

While sight and hearing disabilities are the most talked-about when it comes to web accessibility, cognitive disabilities actually represent the largest number of computer users with disabilities by a substantial margin. So, why aren’t we more aware of cognitive disabilities? Because this type of disability contains a wide range of nuanced ailments and an even wider range of severity, it’s difficult to present a comprehensive set of standards to which web developers should comply. 

\n
\n

In this webinar, we explain some of the different cognitive disabilities from a web developer’s perspective, and then give you a few tips on how to not only meet WCAG standards, but to improve the experience for ALL your users, including those that may have some form of cognitive disability.

\n

We take a look at: 

\n
    \n
  • Functional vs. Clinical Cognitive Disorders\n
      \n
    • Memory, Attention, Comprehension, Autism, Traumatic Brain Injuries, and Dyslexia 
      • \n
    \n
    • \n
  • Ideas for Cognitive Web Accessibility\n
      \n
    • Consistency, logical structure, tables & forms, usability, key board accessibility, captions, and transcripts
      • \n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n 8904665526:\n\n\n\n\n\nHigher Education & The Web: Reaching Your Audience\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
    \n
  • Features
    • \n
  • Industries
    • \n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n

\n
\n
\n

\nHigher Education & The Web: Reaching Your Audience\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/7/14 10:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Finding the right medium for communicating with the most tech-savvy generations can be difficult. With the abundance of devices, platforms, and channels available to students these days, universities and colleges are forced to make difficult choices. Do they focus their attention on a select number of channels, or do they try to spread their efforts across as many as possible in the hopes of reaching the largest audience possible? There may not be a single right answer for every institution, but recent trends should help make finding those answers easier.

\n

The recently published 2014 E-Expectations Report from Noel-Levitz, OmniUpdate, CollegeWeekLive, and NRCCUA sheds some light on how students and their parents prefer to interact with the universities on their wish list. You can get the E-Expectation Report here.

\n

The report provides some interesting findings regarding how students and parents prefer to communicate with universities over a wide range of channels and mediums. Some stats that caught our eye are:

\n
    \n
  • Parents and students both rated college websites as the most influential and reliable recruitment resource by a significant margin.
    • \n
  • 62% of students and 51% of parents prefer web-based resources for learning about prospective universities.
    • \n
  • 67% of students and 59% of parents indicated that a university’s website experience affects their perception of the institution.
    • \n
  • 96% of students and 85% of parents will open an email from a university they are considering.
    • \n
  • 71% of students are viewing university websites on their mobile devices, yet only 41% of them have completed an action, such as requesting information or applying for enrollment.
    • \n
  • Only 51% of students have “liked” a university’s Facebook page, and only 37% have followed them on Twitter.
    • \n
  • Only 38% of students and 50% of parents prefer phone calls and printed materials.
    • \n
\n

 

\n

“Overwhelmingly, students and parents expressed a preference for good website experiences” – 2014 E-Expectation Report

\n
\n
\n

 

\n

While the preference for communication via digital channels doesn’t come as a surprise, the high marks for mobile use, and equally low marks for social media do peak our interest.

\n

Web experiences on mobile devices continue to grow exponentially with each school year. However, many websites (not just university sites) are not able to provide the same experience on a mobile device that they are able to provide with their traditional website. Interacting with forms, downloading information, and viewing videos are often difficult if they have not been properly optimized for mobile platforms. This is evidenced by the fact that of the 71% of students who viewed a site on their mobile device, no more than 41% completed a measurable action.

\n

\n

The lack of interaction between students and universities across social media (shown in the graph below) is a bit surprising, as social platforms should offer a unique opportunity for students to interact in real-time with the university, and for universities to show their unique value proposition. 

\n

\n

The take away here might be to reconsider the content you’re posting to your social feeds. If students and parents are looking to your website for reliable information about enrollment and academic programs, you can help them find it faster by posting it directly to your social feed. By focusing on the most important questions, like degree tracts, faculty or university awards and recognition, or financial aid opportunities, you'll make it easier for your audience to find the information they seek, and develop a stronger connection with your university.

\n

With such a high number of prospective students relying on web interactions before choosing the institution that they will call home for the next 4 years, the statistics presented in the Noel-Levitz report reinforce the importance of having a consistent and high-quality website experience.

\n

Make sure your website is setup to provide the best possible user experience for excited students and discerning parents.

\n

\n \n \n

\n

Top image courtesy of franky242 at FreeDigitalPhotos.net

\n

All data/graph images courtesy of Noel-Levitz 2014 E-Expectations Report at NoelLevitz.com

\n

About Siteimprove

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9028099906:\n\n\n\n\n\nWebsite Content Consistency- Why It's Important and How to Sustain It\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

On-Demand Webinar: Website Content Consistency- Why It's Important and How to Sustain It

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Websites have grown in both size and importance to organizations no matter the industry. At the same time peoples’ expectations for a consistent experience are high and regulations on the web are better defined. How can organizations keep up?

\n

In this webinar we explore- the challenges organizations face, the impact inconsistent content can have and review steps you can take in order to avoid hurting your credibility and negatively impacting your bottom line.

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n    \n
\n
\n
\n

\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n 9028100696:\n\n\n\n\n\nContent Governance in 5 Easy Steps \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

On-Demand Webinar: Content Governance in 5 Easy Steps

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Governance of web content can make headaches and anxiety galore for web masters trying to keep the peace. What are some practical and specific tips you can use to keep your team on the same page and calling your institution by the same name?

What you will learn: In this 45 min webinar, Ahava Leibtag, author of The Digital Crown: Winning at Content on the Web, walks through 5 steps you can use instead of painkillers to whip your content into a cohesive, consistent and polished winner.

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n    \n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n\n

\n

Education

\n

Web governance problems continuously plague educational institutions, as many departments view sites as their own, rather than as a collective part of the institution. As a result, usability suffers as users find sites graphically and textually diverse, and difficult to navigate. Siteimprove can help!

\nRequest a Demo\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove for Education

\n

Work smarter not harder. With Siteimprove for Education it’s easy to assign roles and responsibilities, locate broken links and misspellings, optimize website content for search engines, see WCAG 2.0 and Section 508 issues and make your websites truly web accessible, monitor response times, and help users find the information they need.

\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
    \n
  • \n
    \n

    Quickly Identify Broken Links

    \n

    Siteimprove’s crawlers check every link on every single page of your site so that you don’t have to. With options to filter broken links by internal and external, you can quickly see where the problem lies. Plus run reports at any time to instantly see your progress.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Stress-free Language Management

    \n

    Easily see every spelling mistake on your website, and utilize the powerful dictionary editing features to eliminate false positives and proactively flag inappropriate words. Plus if you were to accidentally add a misspelled word to the dictionary it’s no problem as all changes can be reviewed and edited.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Check website accessibility issues WCAG 2.0

    \n

    Issues and Guidelines in Siteimprove Accessibility checks and identifies the WCAG 2.0 success criteria conformance levels A, AA and AAA for ensuring accessible web content. For instance, missing text alternatives, such as success criteria 1.1.1 Non-text Content which affects screen readers accessing images and even search engine performance. Siteimprove Accessibility also helps list and prioritize errors, flags warnings and allows you to review and ignore WGAG 2.0 issues accordingly.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Check online PDF document accessibility errors

    \n

    As well as scanning web pages for WCAG 2.0 accessibility issues Siteimprove Accessibility also scans all of your site’s PDFs for detectable issues as part of WCAG 2.0 / ISO 14289-1:2012 / Matterhorn Protocol. This includes full document and single page element accessibility issues affecting usability, from missing headings and bookmarks to images without alternative text.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Schedule and Customize Reports

    \n

    Siteimprove Quality Assurance custom reports are delivered directly to your inbox, with prioritized error lists directing your attention to where it’s needed most. Plus generate, schedule and customize unlimited report templates to suit you or your staff’s needs.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

What's included?

\n
\n
    \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    \nExpert Technical Assistance

    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    \nOn-going
    \nTraining

    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    \nOnline Support
    \nServices

    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    \nFull Upgrade
    \nProtection

    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    \nUnlimited
    \nUsers

    \n

Happy clients

\n

Here's what they have to say about us

\n
\n
    \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    As a one-person marketing team, Siteimprove helps me work smarter, not harder. The easy interface and daily reports make it easy to find website errors before customers do. Don’t overlook the opportunity to have a web quality control source so easily available to you!

    \n
    \nMarketing Director at Senn Delaney Leadership Consulting Group, LLC.
    \n
    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    Siteimprove Quality Assurance, quite simply put is indispensable. I manage a higher ed website with thousands of pages and since incorporating Siteimprove into our maintenance schedule I have confidence that users will not find broken links or spelling errors, both which erode our credibility as an institution of higher learning. Whether a broken link is the result of a change from an external site we are linked to or a domino effect from something we have done elsewhere on the site, Siteimprove alerts us to the problem and we can address the issue quickly. The ability to segment and share the reports enables those closest to specific content to be involved in a productive and expedient way.

    \n
    \nAssistant Director of Communications at Cornell University
    \n
    \n
    \n
    • \n

Professional Sports

\n

Your fans have high expectations. Not just for how your team performs, but for the entire fan experience. When they come to your website for the latest news, stats, game times, and tickets, they expect a seamless experience that makes them feel like a part of the organization. Don’t let website errors disrupt their engagement and prevent you from connecting with your best fans.

\nRequest a Demo\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove for Professional Sports

\n

With Siteimprove, your team will be able to identify potential website errors that are preventing your fans from interacting with your brand, such as: broken links, misspellings, and accessibility concerns. We’ll also help you optimize your content for search engines and analyze how pages are performing, which will allow you to create more engaging content in the future.

\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
    \n
  • \n
    \n

    Quickly Identify Broken Links

    \n

    Siteimprove’s crawlers check every link on every single page of your site so that you don’t have to. With options to filter broken links by internal and external, you can quickly see where the problem lies. Plus run reports at any time to instantly see your progress.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Stress-free Language Management

    \n

    Easily see every spelling mistake on your website, and utilize the powerful dictionary editing features to eliminate false positives and proactively flag inappropriate words. Plus if you were to accidentally add a misspelled word to the dictionary it’s no problem as all changes can be reviewed and edited.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Check website accessibility issues WCAG 2.0

    \n

    Issues and Guidelines in Siteimprove Accessibility checks and identifies the WCAG 2.0 success criteria conformance levels A, AA and AAA for ensuring accessible web content. For instance, missing text alternatives, such as success criteria 1.1.1 Non-text Content which affects screen readers accessing images and even search engine performance. Siteimprove Accessibility also helps list and prioritize errors, flags warnings and allows you to review and ignore WGAG 2.0 issues accordingly.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Schedule and Customize Reports

    \n

    Siteimprove Quality Assurance custom reports are delivered directly to your inbox, with prioritized error lists directing your attention to where it’s needed most. Plus generate, schedule and customize unlimited report templates to suit you or your staff’s needs.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Happy clients

\n

Here's what they have to say about us

\n
\n
    \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    We love Siteimprove Response! It revealed that our internet service was at 92-93% uptime, rather than our service provider’s 99% guarantee. We were able to take the data from Response and present it to our Internet Service Provider, who then dramatically improved our service.

    \n
    \nSystems Analyst at Tampa International Airport
    \n
    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    We've seen a 56% increase in average time spent on our website. Quality Assurance makes finding and fixing problem areas on our site much more manageable - we couldn't maintain our site so responsibly without it.

    \n
    \nLead Web Developer at BOSCH Security Systems
    \n

\n\n\n\n\n\n 9089760576:\n\n\n\n\n\nCase Study: University of Wollongong\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

University of Wollongong

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Thank you for requesting our case study!

\n


Click here to download the case study

\n


This case study gives a brief explanation of how the University of Wollongong uses Siteimprove to overcome issues commonly faced by university web teams.

\n
\n

Like to learn more? Click to Request a Demo

\nManaging websites can be tricky, especially the more pages it has, and the more people responsible for its content.

Siteimprove’s Web Governance Suite helps organizations manage and maintain their websites through:
\n
    \n
  • Web Quality Assurance
    • \n
  • Web Accessibility
    • \n
  • Web Analytics
    • \n
  • Search Engine Optimization Analysis
    • \n
  • Web Performance Alerts
    • \n

Museums

\n

When an artist intentionally misspells a word or leaves their work unfinished for effect, they get to call it art. When your website does it, people think it’s unprofessional and it distracts them from the unique experience they came to find. Let us help keep your site looking like art, but functioning like a business.

\nRequest a Demo\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove for Museums

\n

With Siteimprove, your team will be able to identify potential website distractions that are preventing your guests from enjoying their experience, such as: broken links, misspellings, and accessibility concerns. We’ll also help you optimize your content for search engines and analyze how pages are performing, which will allow you to create more engaging content in the future.

\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
    \n
  • \n
    \n

    Access to Complete Inventory

    \n

    Get a comprehensive overview of media files, PDFs, and other documents across multiple websites. Find every instance of sensitive details like email addresses, phone numbers and social security numbers, plus utilize our simple diagrams which show which sites contain what media files, email addresses, and more.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Understand search engine optimization KPIs

    \n

    Siteimprove SEO Performance provides rich and actionable SEO data on how visitors are reaching your website from SERP and external websites. These include referring links and stats on organic keywords used in search engines that have led to specific landing pages with page bounce rates. For SEO purposes, this is very useful information for understanding new visitor searching behavior and building a keyword strategy.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Measure traffic sources and campaign tracking

    \n

    Traffic Sources allows you to view, filter and segment what search engines and external websites have been used to access your website so you can easily attribute access routes. Plus apply Siteimprove Analytics Campaign tracking and Parameters to email, social media and offline advertising so you can home in on which channels are most successfully driving traffic. You can also see external search engine terms, helping you identify what your visitors are searching for to enter your website.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Quickly Identify Broken Links

    \n

    Siteimprove’s crawlers check every link on every single page of your site so that you don’t have to. With options to filter broken links by internal and external, you can quickly see where the problem lies. Plus run reports at any time to instantly see your progress.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Schedule and Customize Reports

    \n

    Siteimprove Quality Assurance custom reports are delivered directly to your inbox, with prioritized error lists directing your attention to where it’s needed most. Plus generate, schedule and customize unlimited report templates to suit you or your staff’s needs.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Happy clients

\n

Here's what they have to say about us

\n
\n
    \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    Siteimprove Quality Assurance, quite simply put is indispensable. I manage a higher ed website with thousands of pages and since incorporating Siteimprove into our maintenance schedule I have confidence that users will not find broken links or spelling errors, both which erode our credibility as an institution of higher learning. Whether a broken link is the result of a change from an external site we are linked to or a domino effect from something we have done elsewhere on the site, Siteimprove alerts us to the problem and we can address the issue quickly. The ability to segment and share the reports enables those closest to specific content to be involved in a productive and expedient way.

    \n
    \nAssistant Director of Communications at Cornell University
    \n
    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    As a one-person marketing team, Siteimprove helps me work smarter, not harder. The easy interface and daily reports make it easy to find website errors before customers do. Don’t overlook the opportunity to have a web quality control source so easily available to you!

    \n
    \nMarketing Director at Senn Delaney Leadership Consulting Group, LLC.
    \n
    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    Every company with a large website should use Quality Assurance from Siteimprove. Nowadays, your website is your brick and mortar, so reputable content and accurate information is key to any brand. Siteimprove will streamline the process and easily point out any errors or inconsistencies.

    \n
    \nInternet Specialist at Saint Joseph Mercy Health System
    \n
    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    The Web Governance Suite is one of our best investments. The quality assurance tool enabled us to clean up a plethora of content on our website, as well as gives us the ability to proactively monitor new material. As someone who deals with a magnitude of software and apps, I can truly appreciate when something comes along that actually makes my life easier.

    \n
    \nManager of Marketing Technology at Blank Rome LLP.
    \n
    \n
    \n

Watch Out, Australia. Here Comes Kelsey.

\n

\nPosted by\nKelsey Johnson\n

\n

\n10/14/14 5:30 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Well, I’m headed down under, to Oz, Aussie, or whatever you prefer to call it – Let me try that again… I’m going to Australia!

\n

Over the past year I’ve had the immense pleasure of working with the Oceania region, and it’s about time that I dropped in for a visit! I’ve been fortunate to build a great network of customers, influencers, and web experts across Australia that I cannot wait to meet with and discuss how Siteimprove can continue to support the needs of web teams around the world, and more specifically, in Australia.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

About Siteimprove

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9028100806:\n\n\n\n\n\nHow to Create Accessible PDFs\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Recorded Webinar: How to Create Accessible PDFs

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

A Step-by-Step Walkthrough for Creating Accessible PDFs

\n

Ensuring that the documents available on your website are accessible for everyone is important for every organization. Unfortunately, the process of actually making your documents accessible to everyone isn't common knowledge. This guide will teach you how to create accessible PDFs using Microsoft Word and Adobe InDesign. 

\n

This full webinar recording covers:

\n
    \n
  • Overview of accessibility guidelines
    • \n
  • How to meet guidelines with Microsoft Word and Adobe InDesign
    • \n
  • Steps for creating accessible PDFs
    • \n
  • How to check PDFs for accessibility
    • \n
\n

This webinar is designed to complement our free guide, "How to Create Accessible PDFs." 

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n

Charles Sturt University

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Thank you for requesting our case study!

\n


Click to Download the case study HERE

\n


This case study gives a brief explanation of how Charles Sturt University, located in Australia, uses Siteimprove to maximise the efficiency of small web teams. 

\n
\n

Like to learn more? Click to Request a Demo

\n

Managing websites can be tricky, especially the more pages it has, and the more people responsible for its content.

\n

Siteimprove’s Web Governance Suite helps organizations manage and maintain their websites through:

\n
    \n
  • Web Quality Assurance
    • \n
  • Web Accessibility
    • \n
  • Web Analytics
    • \n
  • Search Engine Optimization Analysis
    • \n
  • Web Performance Alerts
    • \n

The Challenge of Maintaining Consistent Website Content

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/30/14 11:13 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Updating your website with new content is essential for increasing search traffic, but it can also create content management headaches as your site grows and your content strategy evolves.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why Content Governance Drives Engagement

\n

\nPosted by\nAhava Leibtag\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In honor of President’s Day, my husband and I took our three children to the American Museum of History, a branch of the Smithsonian in Washington, D.C. While we were putting our coats in lockers, I saw something that surprised me:

\n
\n

Does stash seem like a word that is in line with Smithsonian brand? Stash feels a little too irreverent to be a Smithsonian word. Yet, when I saw this sign, it became clear to me:

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

    • \n
  • \nMay 2012 (5)\n
    • \n
  • \nApril 2012 (4)\n
    • \n
  • \nMarch 2012 (3)\n
    • \n

\n

Why You Might Want To Rethink That Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n1/6/15 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Redesigning your website and expecting all of your problems to disappear is like buying a new house because you’re too lazy to clean the one you live in now. Oh, it'll look nice for a while, but eventually you’ll be up to your armpits in clutter again. The same goes for your website. Slapping on a fresh coat of paint might make it look shiny and sleek, but the fundamental problems will remain below the surface.

\n

Spending time, money, and energy on driving traffic to a broken website is a massive waste of resources. Users might be flooding your site, but if all they find are broken links, poor navigation, a lack of direction, and accessibility issues, the frustrating experience will turn them off for good.

\n

The good news? These are all issues that can be addressed on your existing site. So, what can you do instead?

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign,\nWeb Design\n

\n
\n
\n
\nAll posts\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9536461446:\n\n\n\n\n\nWebsite Redesign Checklist\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\nWebsite Redesign Checklist\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/11/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Website redesign. Those two simple words are enough to make even the most seasoned of marketers break out into a cold sweat. Research, planning, meetings, debates, design, user experience, content, development, approvals, and that’s just the process for deciding whether or not you should do a redesign. The sheer amount of work needed to pull off a website redesign is often all it takes to make companies reconsider the whole idea, but it doesn’t have to be.

\n\n

With the right planning upfront, the entire website redesign process will go from big, scary monster, to big, cuddly, digital teddy-bear. Below are some key questions you should answer before you begin your redesign, and a few helpful tips on how to find them.

\n

Define the purpose of your website redesign

\n

“I just don’t like it” won't cut it. You need to identify measurable goals for your website. Where is the current site underperforming and preventing your organization from reaching its goals? How can you address those issues to remedy the situation?

\n

Some issues can be solved by improving the design or user experience. Other issues may require a more technical solution, such as improving the accessibility for disabled users.

\n

Once you’ve identified the problem, the solution won't be far away.

\n

Use data to drive decisions and planning

\n

Analytics data will tell you everything you need to know about how customers reach your site, and how they use it once they get there. Use this data to identify how and why your website isn’t performing well, which pages are getting the bulk of the traffic, and which ones are going unused.

\n

This will allow you to restructure your site in order to make it easier for users to accomplish their goals, instead of forcing them through a sales funnel that only accomplishes your goals. This will also allow you to create a plan for your website’s content, giving the user more of what they clearly want and need.

\n

Audit your existing content

\n

It’s important to know what you have, where it is, and what to do with it. Maybe a particular page should be moved up in the site hierarchy? Maybe you’re missing content on a critical page? By performing an audit of your existing pages and content, you’ll be able to identify areas that need improvement.

\n

Webpage Inventory Audit

\n

The easiest way to do this is to create a spreadsheet of every page on your website, list out the details and contents of the page, its purpose, and the target audience. From there, you can decide where the page should live on your site.

\n
    \n
  • List the URL, Page Title, and Navigation Title
    • \n
  • Determine the purpose of the page
    • \n
  • Identify the target audience
    • \n
\n

Content Audit

\n

On the same spreadsheet as the Webpage Inventory, list out the different types of content present on your site and how they contribute to your website’s goals.

\n
    \n
  • Articles
    • \n
  • Blogs
    • \n
  • Banner ads
    • \n
  • Forms
    • \n
  • Email newsletters
    • \n
  • Event calendars & registration pages
    • \n
  • Images, Audio, Video
    • \n
  • Social media sharing links [Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn, etc.]
    • \n
  • Staff directory etc.
    • \n
\n

The goal here is to get an understanding of how each piece of content contributes to the user experience and, ultimately, your business goals.

\n

Are you spending several hours managing certain content each week, but getting nothing in return? It might be time to reevaluate that content’s place and purpose on the site.

\n

Future Content Considerations

\n

Consider how your site will grow and evolve over time. This will allow you to implement a process that can adapt to your needs, rather than trying to force in a new change after it’s too late.

\n
    \n
  • Will you need an archive for news/blogs?
    • \n
  • Will you need to add pages/sections?
    • \n
  • Who will be responsible for managing new/old content?
    • \n
\n

Create a sitemap

\n

Your sitemap details the hierarchy and structure of the entire site. This document will have a simple look, but it’s crucial to the planning and design of your site.

\n

Think of your sitemap like a family tree. It will detail the order and organization of your pages, and how they’re related to one another.

\n

\n

Create wireframes

\n

Wireframes are similar to a sitemap, in that they are a rough guide to show you how the website will look. However, wireframes are used to show a rough layout of how certain kinds of webpages will look. Don’t worry, you don’t need to create one for every single webpage, just one template for each type of page.

\n
    \n
  • Homepage
    • \n
  • Products
    • \n
  • Blog
    • \n
  • About
    • \n
\n

The wireframe should outline the different areas where content will live on those types of pages.

\n

\n

Establish a web style guide

\n

The web style guide is a set of rules that governs how your site uses/displays things like:

\n
    \n
  • Navigation titles & heading tags
    • \n
  • Paragraphs, lists, and tables
    • \n
  • Links (active, hover, and visited states)
    • \n
  • Images & Videos
    • \n
  • Background images and watermarks
    • \n
  • Sidebars
    • \n
\n

This shouldn’t be confused with your brand guidelines, which dictate how your brand assets are to be used/displayed. The web style guide pertains specifically to how your website is structured and how it presents content.

\n

It’s a lot to consider, but in the long run, having a solid plan in place before you start the process of actually creating your new website will save you time, headaches, and money.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n

\nStep 1: Write Well. Step 2: Be Successful.\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/16/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

The written word has been the cornerstone of human communication since roughly 3,000 B.C. I might be a little biased here, but even as we’ve moved from stone, to pen, to the ever-present keyboard, how you write is more important than ever. The Internet demands good writing. In the Digital Age, your audience’s first interaction with you/your company is often with the words you’ve written. Websites, blogs, social media, email; it’s all vying for the attention of an audience with debilitating A.D.D., and the organizations that prioritize the quality of their web content are the ones who will rise to the top.

\n

\n

Don’t worry, non-English majors, writing well doesn’t mean transforming yourself into the second-coming of Hemmingway, Twain, or Dickinson. You don’t need to fill your paragraphs with complicated prose. Complex writing does not equal good writing. Good writing is simply the result of a clear message, proper grammar and punctuation, and approachability.

\n

So, how can you turn good writing into great web content?

\n

Be original.

\n

If writing well is the foundation, then original writing is the neon-green paint job. It’s what gets you noticed, makes you memorable, and sets you apart from the competition.

\n

Have a voice. Say something different. Say the same thing, but say it better. However you do it, you need to do it in a way that stands out. Be smart, be funny, maybe even a little controversial. Whatever voice you settle on, make sure it’s the one that will resonate with your audience.

\n

If you’re writing for a university who’s trying to appeal to a younger audience, you could explore using verbiage that’s a little more trendy. If you’re writing for a bank, a snarky attitude isn’t likely to convey the level of professionalism that people expect from the institution to which they’ll be entrusting their life savings.

\n

Your company is unique. Write like it.

\n

Give people a reason to care.

\n

Sure, you might be funny or knowledgeable, but that alone won’t keep your readers’ interest. Humor without substance might make a few folks in the cube farm try to smother that giggle, but without a tangible takeaway they’ll probably forget about it once they close their browser window.

\n

On the other side of the coin, being dull and long-winded is a surefire way to bore your readers and send your website’s bounce rate through the roof. 30 pages of research and hard work won’t mean anything if people don’t stick around long enough to read it.

\n

Of course you want people to read your content in the here and now, but you also want them to come back later, you want them to tell others, and you want them all to crave more. With every piece of content you write, ask yourself, “why should anyone care about this?”

\n

People come to your site looking for help, answers, or solutions. It’s your job to show them why you’re the answer to their problem. You need to make people want to do business with you.

\n

Get to the point

\n

The average adult attention span is now eight seconds. That’s one second less than a goldfish.

\n

Don't waste words, but don't gloss over important information.

\n

Say what needs to be said, say it clearly, and let people get on with their day.

\n

Please and thank you.

\n

Be real.

\n

People can tell when they’re being sold to, marketed to, or talked down to. If your content is dishonest, misleading, or patronizing, your audience will tune out long before any usable information is able to sink in. The only thing they’ll remember is the bad experience that they had with your site/company.

\n

Your content should feel natural when it’s being read. Imagine what you would say to your audience if you were having a face-to-face conversation, then write it. You’ll be surprised by how effective content can be when it’s not loaded with sales jargon and marketing catchphrases.

\n

Once you've turned your good writing into great content, make sure it's reaching your audience with this helpful SEO Checklist

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent\n

A Web Governance Framework That Works

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/24/13 4:43 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

The first step in changing Web Governance is often the hardest. There is ample evidence that issues with politics in many organizations have resulted in Governance systems that are extremely resistant to reform. Nevertheless, change must happen eventually. The framework outlined below provides a starting point for this conversation.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n
\n
\n
\n

5 Steps to Ensure PDF Documents are Accessible for Everyone

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/15/13 3:49 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Written by David Herr. PDF content on the web continues to grow each year, despite the issues of ensuring the content is accessible to everyone. It is possible to create completely accessible PDF documents that contain all the rich content and offer the many benefits that PDF files provide. But until recently there have not been good solutions. Manually tagging PDF documents using Adobe® Acrobat Professional is not an easy process and is very prone to errors. Today I will discuss the basic requirements to ensure a PDF document is accessible and can be read using screen reader technology such as JAWS® or NVDA.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website Accessibility Testing: How does your site look to a blind person?

\n

\nPosted by\nMarie Langhoff\n

\n

\n10/8/13 3:52 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove unveiled a new initiative that saw Jacob Nielsen, a blind user, test websites live at the Danish Digitalization Conference as part of its initiative to bring web accessibility for the disabled and handicapped to the forefront of people’s minds.

\n
\n
\n

Jacob, who works as a consultant, is an avid user of the internet and enjoys the self-sufficiency it can offer. However, being blind since he was six months old means he knows all too well how difficult it can be to surf the net if you happen to have a handicap or disability. 

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

What's up with 'not provided'?

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/1/13 3:18 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In 2011, Google began to hide keyword data for encrypted searches, and this only applied to users who were logged into Google. They have now announced however that this will apply to all users and as such will have a significant impact. Up until now, we have been able to provide excellent insight into what keywords our customers’ users used in search engines but in the next couple of months virtually all keyword data from Google will disappear.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Celebrating 10 Years of Siteimprove Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/1/13 1:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Today, 1 October 2013, SaaS company Siteimprove celebrate 10 years of success since first opening in 2003. Having started from humble entrepreneurship roots, Siteimprove has grown exponentially to become a truly successful global company with more than 80 employees, with offices in five countries and customers in 11 countries.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

\n
\n
\n

\nProducing High-Quality Web Content: A Guided Tour\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/9/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

If you're one of those people who can just wake up in the morning, pour yourself a cup of your preferred breakfast-time libation, and start pounding away at your keyboard until something great comes out, we’re officially fighting and I’d like you to leave now.

\n

OK, good. They’re gone.

\n

For us common-folk, creating great content takes time, and it doesn’t happen in a vacuum. It requires a team-effort, as you’ll need input from subject matter experts and buy-in from your co-workers/bosses in order to turn a slab of rock into a piece of chiseled marble.

\n\n

People often ask how long it takes to produce a particular piece of content. That question makes me squirm because it can’t be answered easily. It all depends on the topic, the desired length, the goal, and the amount of research, planning, and approvals that need to be accounted for.

\n

Detailed content, like research or case studies, can easily run over 10 hours (trust me, I know), not including time for approvals and revisions. Smaller “news” articles are a little easier and could possibly be knocked out in under 2 hours if you’re already familiar with the topic.

\n

Let’s lay out the typical process for creating a piece of content and highlight what you can expect from each phase.

\n

Planning/research

\n

If you want to use the word “brainstorming” here, that’s your choice, I won’t judge you too much. I prefer to call it what it really is, the Discovery phase. This is your opportunity to identify all of the dirty details you’ll need for the project.

\n

Use this time to discover:

\n
    \n
  • The topic
    • \n
  • The goal/reason for creating it
    • \n
  • What kind of content it will be (web text, infographic, video)
    • \n
  • How you will gather your information\n
      \n
    • Interviews?
      • \n
    • External data (internal or 3rd party)?
      • \n
    • Existing content (internal or 3rd party)?
      • \n
    \n
    • \n
\n

Basically, this is your chance to ask all the dumb questions you want. And ask them you should! Don’t let things fall through the cracks simply because you assumed incorrectly or because you were too scared/lazy to ask.

\n

Write it

\n

Once you’ve finished planning and gathering intel, it’s time to put on your helmet and get things done!

\n

Turn on your out of office, activate the electric fence, or don your best disguise. Everyone has their own process, but this is your time to lay the groundwork and arrange the pieces of the puzzle.

\n

Structure and flow

\n

Once you’ve got the raw material, you’ll need to identify the “corner pieces” of the puzzle. These are the big chunks of data or information that you’ll use to guide the rest of the process and create content that flows logically and keeps readers engaged.

\n

If you’re writing a study on the growing number of marketing blogs, the “corner pieces” might be things like: global Internet usage data, the breakdown of marketing blog “specialties”, and the most sought after types of content.

\n

Title/heading

\n

The title might be the most important piece of your content. This is the first thing readers will see, and it’s probably the only thing they’ll use when deciding if it will be worth their time to read it.

\n

Titles need to be exciting and engaging, but they also need to be accurate. You can’t mislead readers with titles that aren’t related to the actual content, then it’s just lazy “click-bait”. Stop that!

\n

Quotes and captions

\n

Pick out the best quotes and data and use them when promoting your content to hook readers.

\n

Lay that text over an appropriate, eye-catching image, and you’ve got yourself a ready-made social media post or homepage image.

\n

CTA

\n

You’ve poured blood, sweat, and tears into your content. Mostly sweat. And tears. Lots of tears. Don’t let it go to waste by leaving it with a dead-end. Give the reader something else to do once they’ve finished absorbing your glorious work of art.

\n

Your CTA should provide the reader with the opportunity to find more content, or move to the next step in the conversion process. The important thing to remember with your CTA, is that it should serve the needs of the reader first, and the needs of your business second.

\n

SEO

\n

The Internet is a haystack and your content is the needle. By optimizing your content to perform in online searches, you’ll get a better return on your content creation investment.

\n

Oh, look! A helpful SEO Checklist. How did that get here? Weird.

\n

Review & Revise

\n

Proofread, proofread, proofread. Do it yourself, have your editor do it, have your co-worker do it, have your BFF do it. Heck, have your mom do it (somebody needs to say something nice about it, right?)

\n

The key to proofreading is two-fold. First, you need to get fresh eyes on what you’ve written. You know what it’s supposed to say, but that makes it easy to miss small grammatical errors and confusing sentence structure. Second, you need to get feedback from people with different points of view. This will ensure that every aspect of your content is accurate, consistent, and digestible.

\n

Subject Matter Experts

\n

Have the lead-senior-chief-product-specialist-guy (or whomever your “expert” might be) review your content for factual accuracy. They’re the ones who know what they’re talking about, so getting their sign off is crucial before publishing your content.

\n

Editor/Boss

\n

Most writers will have someone they work with/for who can review their content for consistent branding, tone of voice, and quality.

\n

Your audience

\n

Some writers may even have the good fortune of being able to release their content to a small group of users/readers who can “beta test” it. Other writers may need to rely on co-workers and friends. Try to get them to provide feedback on what they didn’t understand, questions you may have left unanswered, or content that seemed out of place.

\n

Approvals & Publishing

\n

Once you’ve made it through the revision process, it’s time to get the final approval and throw your content to the wolves publish your content.

\n

Hopefully you’re using a CMS that allows you to easily create and modify page elements, like:

\n
    \n
  • Headers
    • \n
  • Meta Description
    • \n
  • Images
    • \n
  • Links
    • \n
\n

Most CMS platforms have plug-ins that allow you to analyze the different pages elements for their SEO performance.

\n

Measure

\n

Publishing your content is only half the battle. From there, you’ll need to monitor how it’s performing. How are people finding it? Is it resonating with your target audience? Is it accomplishing the goal(s) that you identified in the Discovery phase?

\n

Your analytics data tells a story, be sure to read it.

\n

Maintenance

\n

Content should evolve over time. It should be updated with new information, and adjusted to meet the changing needs of its readers.

\n

For small changes, it’s fine to simply update the original content.

\n

For bigger changes, like new study data for example, it’s best to release an updated version of the content which highlights the new data.

\n

For those playing the home game, this blog took a grand total of 3-ish hours to plan, write, optimize, revise, and publish.

\n

\n \n \n

\n

 

\n

Image courtesy of hywards at FreeDigitalPhotos.net

\n

 

\n
\n

How To Quickly Clean Up Disorganized Web Content

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n7/8/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

\n
\n

If you’re feeling overwhelmed by the prospect of cleaning up your website content, the suggestion to “get an overview of your content” may sound glib and unhelpful, but it really doesn’t need to be more complicated than that.

\n
\n

There are plenty of tools available to assist you in putting together an overview, so there’s no reason to ever waste your time manually creating a website inventory.

\n
\nRead More\n

\n

    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Everyone knows reactive marketing is ineffective, but far too many marketers are buried deep under a pile of emergencies to even think about strategic planning. What do you do when your boss comes to your desk every day to light your hair on fire with another emergency?

\n

How to Win Friends and Influence Your Web Team

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n2/5/14 8:52 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Stop me if you’ve heard this one: You’re the website manager, and you’re held responsible for the quality of your web content - but you have content contributors from other departments over whom you hold no real power. That means you’re held accountable for the quality of their work, but have no way to make them actually do it. If they decide not to fix issues that come up, it reflects poorly on you. Fortunately, there are ways to manage this situation! Since you don’t have administrative influence over these team members, you’ll have to rely on relational influence – which is better anyway.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n

6 Ways to Catch Website Issues Before They're a Problem

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/28/14 9:04 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Issues with your website can be absolutely devastating. Despite any of the marketing momentum or client base that you've built up, you may find your traffic ranking and following drastically tanking due to website errors. Lag, bad links, a lack of accessibility and even outdated content can quickly damage a website's SEO and lose the faith of its readership. Luckily, there are some ways you can avoid these issues before they even become a problem.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n
