5 Ways to Determine Your Website's ROI

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/21/14 9:14 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Measuring the ROI of a website is incredibly important. At any time, you may be called upon to prove that the company's website is worth the investment, or even to defend your budget - and that could mean defending your salary, too. The ROI of a website isn't always as simple as presenting "expenses going out" and "profit coming in." Sometimes you may find yourself explaining your website's ROI to individuals who don't even know how to use the web let alone understand its value as a marketing tool. Before you can appropriately measure a website's ROI, upper management needs to have specific marketing, administrative and client service goals for the site in mind. Once you know exactly which metrics the website is being judged on, you can begin calculating the website's return.

\n
\n
\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Maintaining Your Website Saves Time and Headache

\n

\n1/16/14 9:19 AM\n

\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

“I don’t have time to quality assure my site. I’m already swamped with too many other things, and that’ll just have to wait until life settles down a bit.” Sound familiar? Time management is a daily struggle for most website managers, and all too often they deal with pressing deadlines by turning a blind eye to the quality of their website content. Unsurprisingly, this usually doesn't go well. Here are three good reasons why you actually need to keep your site the cleanest when you’re buried under a heavy workload:

\n
\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Siteimprove Announces US Relocation

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/14/14 3:41 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove, the leading provider of Web Governance tools, has relocated their Minneapolis office due to rapid growth in 2013.

\n
\n
\n

On January 2, 2014, Siteimprove US moved into a new office located at 8000 Norman Center Drive, Suite 300, Minneapolis, MN 55437 as part of a major workforce expansion.

\n

Siteimprove’s Minneapolis branch grew significantly in 2013, adding more than 250 new customers and 13 employees.

\n
\nRead More\n

4 Website Tasks You Should Outsource to Robots

\n

    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Every web team is strapped for time, but most have no idea how much time they waste doing things manually when automated options are readily available. Here are four ways you’re wasting time maintaining your organization’s website.

Santa Isn't Real: 4 Common Website Redesign Myths

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n12/12/13 9:38 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Website redesigns tend to be treated as a magic cure for a poor web presence by many digital marketers today. Unfortunately for them, separating fact from fiction can be a sobering wake up call. Here are the top 4 myths surrounding website redesign projects today:

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

5 Reasons You Should Care About Website Errors You're Not Responsible For

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n12/10/13 9:42 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

If an issue on your organization’s website doesn't fall under your area of responsibility, then it’s not your problem, right? Not so fast. Being part of a successful web team means ensuring the entire site is cohesive and error free. That means setting aside the mindset of “not my area, not my fault” and working with your teammates. Because guess what? A problem you pretend not to notice might just land in your lap later on. Here’s why you should care about mistakes in someone else’s jurisdiction. 

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

Marie Langhoff

Recent Posts

\n

\n

Website Accessibility Testing: How does your site look to a blind person?

\n

\nPosted by\nMarie Langhoff\n

\n

\n10/8/13 3:52 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove unveiled a new initiative that saw Jacob Nielsen, a blind user, test websites live at the Danish Digitalization Conference as part of its initiative to bring web accessibility for the disabled and handicapped to the forefront of people’s minds.

\n
\n
\n

Jacob, who works as a consultant, is an avid user of the internet and enjoys the self-sufficiency it can offer. However, being blind since he was six months old means he knows all too well how difficult it can be to surf the net if you happen to have a handicap or disability. 

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\nAll posts\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792123256:\n\n\n\n\n\nThe added bonus of ensuring web accessibility\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\nThe added bonus of ensuring web accessibility\n

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n5/2/12 11:19 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you looking to attract more visitors and retain happier users of your website? If so, then read on! By conforming with a number of accessibility criteria you can not only optimize the accessibility of your website, but also ensure good usability and increased visibility in search engines (SEO).

\n
\n\n

Allow me to give you some examples:

\n

1. Use Headings

\n

The accessibility guidelines prescribe the use of headings (H1, H2… H6) to divide web page content into logical sections, this will also help your ranking in search engines. Visually impaired users can get an overview of a web page and its sections by using the headings that a screen reader brings out. The search engines do the same.

\n

2. Remember alternative descriptions with images

\n

Additionally, the search engines prefer images that have good alternative descriptions. Having these alternative descriptions also helps visually impaired users of screen readers. A blind person cannot see an image and for this reason they need an alternative explanation giving the function of the image. A search engine is also 'blind' and cannot see an image but it can read an alternative text.

\n

3. Write meaningful link text 

\n

A number of criteria for accessibility cover the subject of writing sensible link texts and not just link texts reading 'click here', 'read more' etc. This also helps search engines. If you write a text that says something meaningful about the link destination, both assistive technologies and search engines can make good use of it.

\n

4. Help with input 

\n

When users are to fill out form fields on a web page an accessibility requirement is that you let the user know what is to be filled out, what is mandatory to fill out and at the same time provide help for users who make errors in their entry by giving them tips for correction. This of course helps with the overall usability of your website.

\n

5. Remember validation 

\n

When the accessibility guidelines require that your web pages conform with the current standards for web content, for instance html 4.01 or xhtml 1.0, adhering to this guideline also helps assistive technologies to interpret your content. It helps to ensure platform independence with the effect of having your web pages work and look presentable in different browsers.

\n

6. Enhance user journey

\n

Having an uncluttered and homogeneous website with consistent navigation helps all users. At the same time it is a good idea to give users more than one way of finding web pages such as having a search function, a site map or an index on the website. These are defined accessibility requirements but it is also best practice for the user experience in general.

\n

These points are just a few of the areas where ensuring web accessibility optimizes your website in other areas at the same time. So before you abandon accessibility guidelines thinking they're a hassle, not important, or just for 'a few disabled users' think about the added bonus / side benefits that make your investment valuable for both you and your web users.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

Siteimprove Sponsors Annual NAGW Pinnacle Awards

\n

\nPosted by\nJosh Ditthardt\n

\n

\n9/23/13 10:17 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n

\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove is proud to announce that they will again be sponsoring the Pinnacle Awards at the National Association of Government Webmasters (NAGW) conference, held from September 24-27 in Louisville, Kentucky.

\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n

\n
\n

\nApplying Web Governance\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n1/23/13 2:51 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

It may be one thing to write blog posts about Web Governance, but using it in your day-to-day work is a completely different ball game. In this blog post I’ll show how we’ve tried to apply Web Governance at Siteimprove, and hopefully you’ll learn from our challenges.

\n
\n
\n

A year with Web Governance

\n

When we launched the new Siteimprove website a year ago, I was certain of one thing - We needed to be able to tightly control the website using Web Governance. First and foremost we needed to formulate and write down our Web Governance, as I mentioned in the blog post 'What is Web Governance?'.

\n

Write down your Web Governance

\n

Even though I had decided to scribble down our Web Governance, I quickly came to the conclusion that I was the website owner, and therefore solely responsible for the decisions and work on the website. Therefore why waste time on writing documents that were just for me?

\n

The only things we had on paper were a blog calendar, and guidelines for writing blog posts. The decision to not write anything down soon came back to haunt me, as we started having multiple editors posting jobs, webinars, news and events without any guidelines or procedures to control it.

\n

During the year we've established more procedures, but ultimately it has been done as a reaction to a need or problem, rather than as a proactive approach. The next step then for us now is the take those known procedures and incorporate them into a Web Governance manual. This manual will act as the backbone of established practice for the entire company, and will help new employees to adhere to it.   

\n

Clearly define roles and responsibilities

\n

Shortly after the launch of our new website it became clear that it wasn't feasible to merely have the US and UK websites as translated copies of the Danish website. Each country has its own news and events, and in time the diversity between country sites will only continue to increase. As a result our Marketing Coordinators in the US and UK were assigned content ownership of their respective websites.

\n

The only problem with this was that we hadn't clearly defined the ownership roles. So while copywriting and proofreading were under control it wasn't clear who was responsible for following up website usage with Siteimprove Analytics, or who maintained our internal search function.

\n

Now that we have added German and Swedish websites as well, the need for clearly defined roles and responsibilities is even more relevant.

\n

Use policies and procedures

\n

In a previous blog post I wrote about the policies and procedures of Web Governance. At Siteimprove we've primarily worked with procedures that describe how we do things; How do we ensure that images are cropped correctly, how do we post on social media, how do we structure job postings etcetera. This has helped us a lot in terms of ensuring uniformity across the board.

\n

You may ask yourself, "then why should I spend time writing down policies if there's already a set of procedures explaining how to do different tasks?" Policies are "laws," and they can guide you when you run into tasks for which you don't have procedures. Now while procedures may explain how to do a specific task, it is the policies that provide you with a reason as to why tasks should be solved in a specific way. And therefore they ease the implementation of Web Governance in the organization, as everybody is on the same page.

\n

One of the policies that we've spent time on is our language policy. It defines the tone of voice we use in our communication, both internally and externally, and also explains why we've chosen that specific voice. Our language policy is strongly rooted within our corporate strategy and our corporate values.

\n

The future

\n

During the next year we will improve our Web Governance and make it available to all within Siteimprove. This includes further defining roles and responsibilities, formulating more procedures, and the creation of further policies. This work will be tightly bound to our continued work strategy, ensuring that Web Governance and web strategy are aligned with our corporate strategy.

\n

Next time we get a new website, we'll think about Web Governance from day one, as it really does make the task easier and more comprehensible.

\n

If you've been involved in the creation or implementation of Web Governance, we would love to hear your thoughts in the comment section.

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792140176:\n\n\n\n\n\nLend the Search Engines a helping hand\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n
\n

\nLend the Search Engines a helping hand\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n8/15/12 4:45 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

If Google or other search engines can’t read the content on your website, they won't show your pages in the search results.

\n
\n

When you've taken the time to produce content for your website, you probably want it to be found and read by your target audience. Since the vast majority of users use search engines when surfing the web, it's a good idea to help the search engines in easily reading your content. Therefore, it's essential that your website is 'search engine friendly' in the sense that you should make technical and structural enhancements to your website to make it easier for search engines to read.

\n\n

Technical changes to the website are just a small part of Search Engine Optimization (SEO), but they're a good place to start. If the search engines can't read your website, then all other optimizations are a waste of time.

\n

With this and subsequent blog posts, we want to help you get started in making your website more easily readable for search engines and thus more find useful for your customers. After reading this post, you should have an urge to start search engine optimizing your website.

\n

So where do you begin?

\n

Some of the most common ways that websites trip over themselves:

\n
    \n
  • The pages are competing among themselves for the search engines' attention. If a search engine thinks that two or more pages on your website are about the same subject, it won't know which to place higher in the rankings. This can happen if multiple pages have the same main heading or title (called " Duplication").A helpful trick is to think of the title of a web page the same way you'd think of the title of a book: It should be unique while still suggesting what the page is about. If you saw two books on a shelf with the same title and author, you'd probably assume they're the same book and just grab one or the other. Search engines do that too, so make sure that your titles and headlines are unique and descriptive of the content.
    • \n
  • The pages are blocked from being found and indexed by search engines.  There are several techniques to prevent search engines from finding a page. These are very useful for keeping people from accidentally finding your unfinished website during development and testing, but people often forget to unblock the search engines when the page is finished. If search engines don't show your pages in the results, you lose a large percentage of users who would otherwise be finding and using your website.
    One way of limiting search engine access is to put a small text file titled "robots.txt" at the root of your website that contains rules on what search engines are allowed to read.
    Another way is to have a meta-tag called "meta robots" embedded in the page code that tells search engines whether or not they can read and index the page. Make sure that the pages you want to be found by Google and other search engines are not restricted by robots.txt and meta robots.
    • \n
\n

If you take the plunge into SEO, tell us how it goes in the comments below!

\n

If you don't quite know how to get started you can try our Siteimprove SEO tool, which among other things, highlights the places where your website competes with itself.

\n

You can also write to me, Bo Vejgaard, and I'd be happy to answer your questions.

\n
\n \n \n
\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

  • \nSeptember 2014 (5)\n
    • \n
  • \nAugust 2014 (6)\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792150876:\n\n\n\n\n\nSiteimprove's Webinar: Why Making PDF Accessible Documents is Important \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Webinar: Why Making PDF Accessible Documents is Important

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Wednesday, March 26, 2014 at 1pm CDT

\nMaking your PDF documents accessible is important so that all users are able to access your information—no matter its format. Not only is making your content accessible a best practice, some companies are also required to maintain accessibility and follow standards from Section 508 of the Rehabilitation Act as amended in 1998.

What you will learn:
\n
    \n
  • Why and How to define an accessible document
    • \n
  • When to use vs. not use PDF files
    • \n
  • Alternatives for PDF content
    • \n
  • Where to start when creating PDF documents
    • \n
\n

About the Host:

\n

Kevin Rydberg is Siteimprove’s Senior eAccessibility Consultant, in the US office he is responsible for guiding and supporting businesses and organizations on their journeys to create accessible websites.

\n

Optional Extra: Stick around after the webinar for a quick 15 min overview of our Web Governance Suite software.

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n   \n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n© 2015 Siteimprove Inc\n

\n
\n
\n
\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n 9792128196:\n\n\n\n\n\nHow Web Accessibility Can Boost Your SEO\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
    \n
  • Features
    • \n
  • Industries
    • \n
  • Knowledge
    • \n
  • About
    • \n
\n

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n

\n
\n
\n

\nHow Web Accessibility Can Boost Your SEO\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/6/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

In case having a website that’s accessible to all users wasn’t enough incentive on its own, here’s another reason- it will help boost your SEO rankings. Yeah, true story. On the surface it may not seem like the two are connected, but behind the subtle scenes of your website’s code, proper accessibility practices are providing a major boost to your SEO. What’s that idiom about birds and stones? 

\n\n

Website accessibility means creating an online environment in which all users, not just those with disabilities, are able to easily navigate, interact with, and understand the web. Having a website that features intuitive navigation, properly labeled links and images, and user friendly design aesthetics will result in users spending more time on your site, consuming your content, and engaging with your brand. For more information on web accessibility, read our various web accessibility blogs

\n

SEO refers to the curation of your site’s content in order to enhance your ranking in organic web searches. However, Google continues to adjust their search algorithm in order to combat dishonest SEO practices, like keyword stuffing and link building, so you’ll want to make sure you’re up to speed on the latest rules by reading our blog about the evolving SEO landscape.

\n

It may seem daunting, but the good news is that you can improve your site’s accessibility and SEO without needing to be a professional web developer or SEO expert. Let’s take a look at some of the ways in which you can improve your site’s accessibility and SEO today.

\n

If you like what you read here, be sure to download the Accessibility & SEO Webinar from our Senior eAccessibility Consultant, Kevin Rydberg.

\n

Link Text

\n

How it Impacts Human Users & Assistive Devices

\n

Link text refers to the hyperlinked words, phrases, or sentences within page content. This text is intended to inform users of where the link will be taking them, or the type of content to which the link is directed.

\n

Link text should be as descriptive as possible in order to avoid confusion and frustration. Clicking the “back” button in your browser may not seem like a complicated task for many of you, but for physically or visually impaired users, it may not be so simple.

\n

Another reason to provide detailed link text is that screen readers allow visually impaired users to navigate webpages via a list of internal links, so ten links all titled “Click Here” would be of no help.

\n

“Click here” or “Read more” = Bad Link Text

\n

“Read more about SEO and Web Accessibility” = Good Link Text

\n

How it Impacts Search Engines

\n

Link text also informs search engines of where hyperlinks are directed, but, like screen readers or text-to-speech platforms, they are only able to read the HTML code verbatim, they can’t imply a destination based on associated text. Context matters to search engines, particularly Google, who are now rewarding sites which provide high-quality content and links to other reputable sites.

\n

If your link text reads, “Click here”, the search engine will interpret this as the title or subject of the page to which you're linking. More specific link text, such as, “See the Top 10 Vacation Destinations”, allows the search engine to identify Vacation Destinations as the topic and factor it into your site’s ranking when users search for “Vacations” or “Vacation Destinations”

\n

Image Descriptions

\n

How it Impacts Human Users & Assistive Devices

\n

Screen readers don’t have eyes. They navigate sites by reading the HTML code, and image descriptions enable them to identify what the image is depicting and properly relay that information to users.

\n

Take the image below. While it may be obvious to some users that the image is showing the Chrysler Building and downtown Manhattan, it is not obvious to assistive devices like screen readers or text-to-speech software.

\n

\n

The assistive device only knows that this is an image because the code used to embed this image on a website uses the HTML image <img> tag, which looks like this:

\n

<img src="images/071014-DSC_01.jpg"/>

\n

However, this still does not tell the screen reader what the image is depicting. In order to help, you should rename the file with a descriptive filename, as well as adding some alternative, or “alt” text to the <img> tag, like so:

\n

<img src="images/chrysler_building.jpg" alt="View of Manhattan and the Chrysler Building"/>

\n

This alternative text is also useful for users with a slow internet connection, incompatible web browser, or who have chosen to not load images, as it provides a description of the image even if it isn’t loaded. A further description of the function of the “alt” attributes can be found on the W3C website.

\n

Another not-so-fun fact: Without “alt” text, devices like screen readers will read the image file name word for word, number for number, and character for character, even if it's complete jibberish. However, if it identifies “alt” text within the HTML, it will automatically skip to this text and save the user from a potentially frustrating and confusing situation.

\n

How it Impacts Search Engines

\n

Image descriptions are just as important for search engines. By providing an accurate file name and descriptive “alt” text, search engines will be able to identify that your site includes relevant images that support its content and reward you for its relevancy.

\n

Semantic Markup

\n

How it Impacts Human Users & Assistive Devices

\n

Semantic Markup refers to the practice of employing properly structured HTML code which clearly identifies the content sections of your site, like headers, navigation, articles, footers, etc. Doing so will give your website a logical layout that is easy for both human users and assistive devices to navigate.

\n

Proper site navigation results in a better experience where content and information are easy to find, interact with, and understand. Being able to find what they're looking for means more user time spent on your site, which results in higher SEO rankings.

\n

How it Impacts Search Engines

\n

Search engines crawl websites’ HTML systematically; they start at the top and work their way down. So if your most important content is clearly labeled near the top of the page’s HTML (page headers/navigation), the search engine will be able to easily identify what your page content is all about and reflect that in your SEO ranking.

\n

Hopefully this blog was able to help you improve your website's accessibility and SEO practices, but feel free to post and questions or feedback in the comments section below!

\n
\n

 

\n

Our Senior eAccessibility Consultant, Kevin Rydberg recently recorded an on-demand webinar that covers how Web Accessibility can boost your SEO.

\n

  \n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792132726:\n\n\n\n\n\nUse Web Governance to Secure a Strong Foundation for Your Search \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\nUse Web Governance to Secure a Strong Foundation for Your Search \n

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n11/28/12 3:08 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Who is in control of your internal search? If you want your search to work well you should include it in your web governance.

\n
\n\n
\n

As mentioned in previous blog posts about web governance; the purpose of web governance is to make sure each employee knows what their responsibilities are in terms of the website, and what is expected of them. This is also the case when you work with the website's search function.

\n

Website search and web governance

\n

If you look at your website search from a web governance perspective, you'll find many areas of responsibility for which you'll need to have procedures and clearly appointed responsibilities. There are strategic decisions about what types of content you want to be available through the search function and how different content types should be prioritized. You also need to consider maintenance of search results, individual page searchability, and analysis of search statistics including; the presentation of findings.

\n

You'll typically have many different persons and roles sharing these responsibilities, and not just one person who is responsible for everything search related.

\n

Take individual page searchability as an example. This is about ensuring that the technical structure of the page makes it easy for the search engine to read and understand it, but it is also about making sure that the content on the page is written in a clear language so it is obvious what the page is about and how it differs from other pages on the website. These are two very different tasks, but they have the same overall purpose. This is an example of why clear areas of responsibility and procedures are important.

\n

Roles and Responsibilities

\n

The following are some of the tasks and areas of responsibilities that should be planned for in your web governance. These are coupled with roles, as examples of how it could be. There is no right way to do this, as roles and responsibilities depend on the size and ambitions of your web team.

\n
    \n
  • Aligning search with web strategy: This task is typically handled by the web team leader and includes deciding which content types to index and prioritize. Should self-service solutions and news content be prioritized higher than minutes from meetings and PDFs?
    • \n
  • Maintenance of search result pages: This task includes making custom rankings for specific searches (most popular, searches without results, or focus areas). This is done with the web strategy in mind and an eye on the analysis of search statistics. The task is normally handle by a central web team, but preferably by local editors responsible for a specific area.
    • \n
  • Analysis and interpretation of search statistics: This is often carried out by the central web team or a dedicated web analyst. It is important to have procedures for how and whom the results of the analysis is presented, so you make sure this knowledge is used.
    • \n
  • Control of 3rd party solutions and new solutions: All websites are in constant development; this means introducing new solutions and from time to time 3rd party solutions. If these new solutions contain information that should be available through the search function, it is important to have procedures for ensuring their searchability.
    • \n
\n

These are just some of the areas that you need to take into consideration in your web governance. It is important that you map the need of your organization, so you get into every corner.

\n

If you have subsites or sections on your website which have a search function of their own, then you might need more persons with the same responsibility but for different sections, while other responsibilities might be handled centrally for all the solutions.

\n

If you use specialized or advanced searches it is important that the responsibility for maintaining these is assigned.

\n

Web standards

\n

Most of the areas of responsibility should be supported by web standards, which define one specific way to do a task. Web standards will help you by eliminating doubts and making the website appear uniform. It is a great idea to spend some extra time on developing reasonable web standards.

\n

Here are some examples of web standards:

\n
    \n
  • Headings/titles of search results must be unique to avoid confusing users
    • \n
  • Self-service solutions should have the highest priority where applicable
    • \n
  • All searches that are made more than 20 times a month must have results
    • \n
  • All searches without results should be reviewed at least once a month
    • \n
\n

Summary

\n

A search function can be of great help to the users of the website, but it will need to work properly. Therefore, it is a good idea to include search responsibilities in your web governance.

\n

A well-functioning search can save your organization time and money, because users who find what they need on your website won't use the more expensive channels of communication. At the same time a good search function will provide you with valuable information about user's needs, which can be used in future work with your web strategy.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792143236:\n\n\n\n\n\n9 Ways to Keep Your Search Rankings During a Website Redesign\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n

\n

\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n

\n9 Ways to Keep Your Search Rankings During a Website Redesign\n

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n9/12/12 4:28 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Getting a new website can be like walking into a minefield in terms of search engine optimization. Worst case scenario, you could lose all your search engine rankings and will have to start from scratch. Luckily, this doesn’t have to happen - as long as you do the transition the right way.

\n
\n\n
\n

The most important thing to remember is that the search engines are an important part of the target audience for your new website. If you make sure that it's easy for the search engines to understand the changes you've made, (including domain, site structure, links, and so on) you'll increase the chances that you make it through the transition without dropping in the search results. You might even come out ahead.

\n

Here is a list of nine things to do to avoid losing search engine rankings when getting a new website.

\n

1. Redirects

\n

If getting a new website also means getting new URL's for the pages, it's important that you use 301 redirects to inform the search engines that the content has permanently moved to a new location. This way the search engines know that the new pages have the same or similar content, and it's safe to assign the same rank to the new page. This is also the case even if it's only the extension of the page that you change. (e.g. "http://example.com/default.html" is changed to"http://example.com/default.aspx")

\n

You have to make sure that every page on the old website has a 301 redirect set up, which points to the same content on the new website. It's a bad idea to make a general redirect that redirects all the old pages to the home page of the new website, because this will annoy users and search engines alike. If it isn't possible to do a one-to-one match between old and new pages, you should at least have the old pages point to a new page with similar content. If this isn't possible to do automatically and you have too many pages to do it manually, try to do it for your most important and most visited pages.

\n

2. Change of domains

\n

If the transition from the old website to the new website includes a change of domain name, you should consider breaking the process down into two separate steps. First move the old website to the new domain, setting up 301 redirects to one-to-one. After this is done (ensuring it has worked), then launch the new website on the new domain, again with correct redirects. This will minimize the risk of something going wrong in the process.

\n

3. Backlinks

\n

Collect usage stats of referring links to your website (backlinks) and identify the most popular of these. This information can typically be found in an analytics or SEO tool, such as Siteimprove SEO. Ideally you would contact the owners of referring websites and have them change the link to point to your new page, but this isn't practically possible. You should however try to contact the owners of the most popular backlinks and have these changed, and make sure that the pages which the rest of the backlinks point to are properly 301 redirected.

\n

4. Page titles and meta descriptions

\n

Make sure that all pages on the new website have page titles and meta descriptions. You can transfer these from the old website - if (and only if!) they are unique and descriptive of the page content. If you haven't focused on creating search engine friendly page titles and meta descriptions yet, now is a great time to get started.

\n

5. Sitemap

\n

When you launch your new website it's a good idea to have 2 complete sitemaps configured: an HTML sitemap for users and search engines, and an XML sitemap for search engines only.

\n

An XML-sitemap can be submitted to the search engines through their webmaster tools (Google Webmaster Tools & Bing Webmaster Tools) which helps them crawl and index your website faster.

\n

6. 404 Page not found page 

\n

Create a 404 Page Not Found page that's both user friendly and search engine friendly. Even though you've created 301 redirects for all content on your old website it is still important to monitor 404 errors. A good 404 page will help the users and search engines get back on track in an easy way. One way to do this could be to implement a search box on the 404 page, so users easily can search for what they actually looked for. It is also a good idea to keep the menu of the website on the 404 page for increased usability.

\n

Besides having a user friendly 404 page, it is also very important that the page actually returns a http code 404 so search engines are made aware that they followed a broken link. You should also ensure that you have tracking on your 404 page, so you can identify the referrers and fix the broken links. If you aren't careful you could end up having the 404 page being one of the most visited pages on your new website.

\n

7. Robots.txt 

\n

Review and update your robots.txt file, if you have one on your old website. The robots.txt file is used to inform search engines about pages you don't want crawled and/or indexed. This should be updated to match your new URL structure.

\n

It's also important to make sure that any development or test websites aren't crawled as this can result in duplicate content issues. In this case, it's a good idea to use robots.txt to block the search engines, and at the same time add password protection as an extra level of security.

\n

8. Avoid broken links

\n

Use a quality assurance tool such as Siteimprove Quality Assurance to ensure that there are no broken links on the website. Even though you've set up 301 redirects for all your old content, problems can still arise, especially if some of the old pages employ absolute URLs in the links instead of relative URLs (e.g."http://example.com/users/foo.aspx" vs. "/users/foo.aspx").

\n

9. Transition period

\n

Last but not least, Google recommends that if you have changed your domain name, you keep the old domain name with the 301 redirects for at least 180 days as a period of transition.

\n

If you follow these nine simple tips you minimize the risk of your website disappearing from the search engines in the transition. Just remember that it can be of great advantage to think about search engine optimization as part of the brainstorming and design phase when you are starting your new website project. If you are getting a new website regardless, why not make it search engine friendly from the beginning?

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792145126:\n\n\n\n\n\nThe Foundations of a Website Redesign\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nThe Foundations of a Website Redesign\n

\n

\nPosted by\nStar Bazella\n

\n

\n8/19/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Embarking on a website redesign is no small undertaking. It will require a substantial amount of strategy, organization, and company soul-searching. Not only will you need to ask difficult questions, but you’ll need to provide answers that satisfy every major stakeholder. This prospect alone is enough to deter some organizations from pressing forward, but there are steps you can take in order to not only streamline your redesign project, but ensure that everyone’s needs are met.

\n

\n

Why Redesign Your Website?

\n

Before we get into the specifics, let’s ask my favorite question: “why”? What is the problem with your current website, and what is your goal for the new website?

\n

For some organizations, their current site is simply outdated and needs to be modernized in order to compete in a crowded digital market. For others, the functionality of their site isn’t helping them to achieve their online goals (driving sales, providing information, boosting awareness, etc.)

\n

Before you even begin to think about redesigning your site, you need to answer, “why?”

\n

Content Inventory Audit

\n

Now that you’ve determined why your website needs to be redesigned, and what your goals are, you can begin the process of organizing your assets through a Content Inventory Audit.

\n

This is a simple spreadsheet of all your existing webpages and their corresponding URLs. A Content Inventory Audit is a task often done toward the beginning of a website redesign project, and essential for any [website or intranet] content migration project. It is a great way to think through a redesign but may not be the best way to plan a completely new website.

\n

The spreadsheet stores information about each page on the website; a very handy tool that provides a quick overview of your site.

\n

For most of my projects, I like to collect:

\n
    \n
  • Navigation title, page title and URL for every page
    • \n
  • What's the purpose of the page?
    • \n
  • Who is the target audience of that page?
    • \n
  • More criteria will be covered in the upcoming webinar…
    • \n
\n

As you prepare to add content to the website, think about who will contribute. In a five-person business, it might be just two of you, and that’s fine. In a large business or organization, 5, 10 or 15 people might be contributing content. The time required to edit and proofread both copy and visual content grows exponentially in relation to the number of people who contribute content.

\n

Unless you are creating the most technical website imaginable, your content should consist of more than just plain text. By using one or more of the following multimedia elements, you’ll greatly enhance the appeal and usefulness of the website:

\n
    \n
  • Images & Photo Feeds (Flickr)
    • \n
  • Documents (preferably PDFs)
    • \n
  • Embedded Audio & Video (YouTube & Vimeo)
    • \n
  • Social Media Feeds (Twitter, YouTube, Google+, LinkedIn)
    • \n
  • RSS feeds
    • \n
\n

Content Checklist

\n

Once you’ve mapped out your existing webpages, you can begin to look at the specific content contained within them. The type of content you’re creating will obviously vary depending on your organization’s goals and your audience’s needs, but here is a list of the most common content- this is not even close to an exhaustive list.

\n
    \n
  • Articles
    • \n
  • Blogs
    • \n
  • Banner advertising
    • \n
  • Forms
    • \n
  • Email newsletter
    • \n
  • Event calendar & registration
    • \n
  • Images, Audio, Video
    • \n
  • Social media sharing links [Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn, etc.]
    • \n
  • Staff directory etc.
    • \n
\n

Future Content Considerations

\n

Now it’s time to think about future expansion. For example, you might start out with six news items in your news section, each with brief summaries and links to the full view of the item. But what happens when you have 10, 20 or 50 news items? Do you want to archive old news? Paginate the items? Show only the last 10 items? Consider these questions in the design process.

\n

For websites that accumulate content, such as news, press releases and reports, there’s a good rule to follow when creating mock-ups (you can never have enough mock-ups!) In other words, if you think the layout or design of a page or section of the website will differ significantly from other pages, then mocking it up is worthwhile. This step normally comes after the initial mock-ups are approved.

\n

Sitemaps 

\n

A sitemap lists the structure and content of the whole site, roughly similar to the "table of contents" in a book. A sitemap can be an effective planning tool for both designers and non-designers.  It’s a centralized document that can help organize and clarify the content on your site, as well as help you identify future pages and eliminate unnecessary pages.

\n

Sitemaps are made for visitors (people), but they also serve the secondary function of giving search engine crawlers an easy way to find the pages of your site. It is always important to remember when you are making decisions about your site to make those decisions with your visitors first and search engines second.

\n

\n

In the webinar, we’ll cover the different ways to design a sitemap, and the difference between HTML Sitemaps and XML Sitemaps.

\n

Wireframes

\n

Once you’ve determined the structure of the content, you can move to the first step in the design process. Wireframes! A wireframe contains the core components of an individual page, communicating hierarchy, user interface patterns, logic, content types, and potential structure. It’s a representation of how the website interface might work. It is NOT the final visual design or layout.

\n

There are many great tools for this:

\n
    \n
  • Photoshop, Illustrator and Visio works well,
    • \n
  • Specialized tools, like Balsamiq, are my personal favorite
    • \n
\n

\n

It’s important to avoid the desire to make everything look perfect in a wireframe. This phase of the process is meant to help you guide the design, not actually be the design.

\n

You should create a wireframe for each unique page on your site (Homepage, product page, contact page, etc.) It isn’t necessary to create a wireframe for every product page, unless you intend for them to have significantly different layouts and functionalities.

\n

Once the wireframes have gone through your review process with the powers that be, NOW you are allowed to move to the design stage.

\n

Web Style Guide

\n

Last, but not least, in planning out the structure of your website, a Web Style Guide needs to be developed, especially if there are multiple content contributors to your site.

\n

A style guide is where proper planning shines, as it will define all of the design, layout, interactive and type elements used throughout the website.

\n

These include, but are not limited to:

\n
    \n
  • Navigation styles
    • \n
  • <h1> through <h5> (heading tags)
    • \n
  • Paragraphs
    • \n
  • Lists
    • \n
  • Links, including active, hover, and visited states
    • \n
  • Icons
    • \n
  • Use of images and image style
    • \n
  • Use of background images (watermarks)
    • \n
  • Common elements such as sidebars
    • \n
\n

A style guide can also help you start to pay attention to web accessibility standards. If you’re not familiar with web accessibility practices, check out our catalog of web accessibility blogs.

\n

\n \n \n

\n

Image courtesy of phasinphoto at FreeDigitalPhotos.net

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n

\nMichelle Blair\n
\n

\nStar Bazella\n
\n
\nThanks Michelle! Tell your friends :)\n
\n

\nJennifer MILLER\n
\n
\nHi this looks great, will the webinar be recorded and able to access at a later date?\n

\nStar Bazella\n

\nHarry Jansen\n
\n
\nRevamping a website is no easy task. All the considerations given below, with particular reference to content should be undertaken. Future content considerations, site mapping, space for digital marketing have to be followed. A well written blog on the foundations of a website redesign. Found it to be very useful. Keep posting.\n

\n
\n

\nWhy Blogging Should Be Part Of Your Web Governance Strategy\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n6/24/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

The “too long; didn’t read” version? It’s good for business. Oh, you’re still there. Well then let’s elaborate on that a little bit. When done correctly, blogging is arguably the most important, and most effective, inbound marketing tactic your organization can utilize. According to HubSpot, blogging regularly will result in more sales leads, more site visits, and more social media engagement. See? We told you it’s good for business.

\n

Now, for you detail-oriented readers, let’s take a closer look at how blogging can have a positive impact on your other marketing and web governance strategies and help you reach your online marketing goals.

\n\n

Increased Site Traffic

\n

Not just any traffic, RELEVANT traffic. How do you know if it’s relevant traffic? Good question. Blogging adds unique pages to your website, and more unique pages will create more opportunities for you to show up in online searches.

\n

Typically, blogs focus on a specific topic that will resonate with users who are looking for specific answers, so over time you’ll be positioning your organization to answer any questions that your audience might have. The result? More opportunities to attract relevant traffic. However, this can be a double edged-sword…

\n

SEO

\n

While more pages and more traffic are a good thing, they’ll be worthless if you’re not producing high-quality content. As we discussed in a recent blog, the SEO landscape is evolving. Google’s search algorithm has been refined to reward the sites that produce the content its users are searching for, and penalize the sites that don’t.

\n

It won’t happen overnight, but if you’re playing by Google’s rules and putting out consistently high-quality content (the kind that is relevant to search terms and links to reputable sources), you’ll begin to see a bump in your organic search rankings.

\n

Social Media

\n

If you don’t have a robust social media strategy, or you’re always freaking out over what to post, your blog provides the perfect solution. Not only does it give you something relevant to share with your followers, it allows you to engage them in a deeper conversation, which stretches the reach and impact of your blog.

\n

It also gives your followers something to share, and then they’ll tell two friends, and they’ll tell two friends…

\n

Sales Leads/Conversions

\n

Blogs play an integral part in the sales conversion process. Whether they’re a customer’s initial entry point to your site or the final touch point before a conversion, your blogs can be used to drive readers through the appropriate stages of the conversion process.

\n

Every blog should have a relevant Call-to-Action (CTA) that encourages the reader to take the next step, whether it’s requesting a demo, downloading a document, or watching a video. This removes any barriers that might prevent a successful conversion.

\n

Thought Leadership

\n

The goal is for your organization to become synonymous with the product/service you provide. You want to be Kleenex®, not the company that makes facial tissues. By continuing to provide the information and guidance that your audience is looking for, you’ll demonstrate your knowledge of the topics that they find important and earn their trust.

\n

Over time, blogging will help establish your organization as a trusted industry resource, or “thought leader”, and the encourage people to seek you out first for answers to their questions.

\n

Quality Customer Interaction

\n

Blog interactions go beyond likes and shares, as they allow your readers to ask specific question about the topic you just covered. Your blog is the perfect medium for engaging your audience and demonstrating how your organization can help them solve a problem or provide a solution for their needs.

\n

 

\n

Developing a blog editorial calendar will help you map out key topics and be proactive about the content you’re providing. Don’t be afraid to ask your audience for feedback, because ultimately their needs should dictate what you’re blogging about.

\n

Need some help to get started in the right direction? Download our on-demand webinar for 5 helpful content governance tips.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792146526:\n\n\n\n\n\nRoles & Responsibilities on Website Teams\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n

\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\nRoles & Responsibilities on Website Teams\n

\n

\nPosted by\nShane Diffily\n

\nFind me on:\n
\nTwitter \n
\n
\n

\n

\n6/3/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

People are the most important part of any system of Web Governance. Hire good people and they will generally find clever and innovative ways to get maximum bang for your buck. However, roles & responsibilities have not kept pace with changes in online activity. This has led to dangerous gaps in operations, as well as tension among staff due to competing claims over “who does what”.

\n

In this article we’ll explore some of the ways you can restore 'industrial peace' by delivering the clear job descriptions your team needs.

\n

\n

On a Web Team where everyone knows what they should (& should not) be doing, all tasks have a go-to-guy and nobody has to worry about stepping on a colleague's toes. 

\n

On a site with low volumes of activity, this is straightforward because everything can be done by a single web-guy. Indeed, it is still common to find sites where a 'Jack-of-all-trades’ type Webmaster looks after all design, content, code, analytics, marketing and more.

\n

The only problem is that this 'all-in-one' model can’t last forever.

\n

Growing pains

\n

As a site grows in scale, a single webmaster won’t have the time (or the skills) to do everything. As a result, new staff must be hired and new roles & responsibilities created.

\n

The diagram below illustrates how this typically happens.

\n

\n

As you can see, when scale increases the Webmaster begins to step back from day-to-day activity and devolve responsibility to newly created roles. Among the first tasks to be handed-over are those in core skill areas such as hosting, code, design and content, followed by marketing, analytics and more.

\n

To keep things running smoothly, it is important you have a clear system for defining boundaries between new positions as change occurs. While the terms “roles” and “responsibilities” are often used interchangeably, they do in fact have quite distinct meanings.

\n

A “role” represents the key competence or activity for which a staff member is hired, while “responsibilities” are a description of the outcomes expected of that person.

\n

For instance, the role of Developer may be filled by someone hired for her coding skills, while her responsibilities are to produce code that adheres to best practice and organizational standards.

\n

If the shoe fits

\n

Of course, this is not to suggest that responsibilities must always be limited to a staff member’s basic skills. The real world doesn't work like this.

\n

Budget restrictions mean that people usually end up doing things that aren’t really within their remit, but nevertheless still need to be done.

\n

Most Web Teams incorporate some woolliness in this regard and it is common for the responsibilities of team members to be much wider than suggested by their titular roles.

\n

For example, responsibility for analytics on a mid-scale site may be allocated to a Content Producer or Designer even though traffic & data analysis are core to neither.

\n

(Happily, many staff have broad enough skills to cope, perhaps with the support of training.)

\n

‘Peak geek’ has been passed

\n

The good news is that as a site grows, much of this fuzziness fades away and staff can begin to focus almost exclusively on their own expertise.

\n

Indeed, a notable trend in Web Governance is the ongoing specialization of digital roles.

\n

While a decade or more ago you could run a site based on a team with broad code, design and content skills – this is no longer true.

\n

The arms race to develop ever more sophisticated websites has led almost every skill set to fragment into a series of incredibly niche disciplines.

\n

In fact, we have long surpassed the point of ‘peak geek’, where any one person could have a practical working knowledge of every web specialism.

\n

\n

From Content Marketing to User Experience Design to Universal Analytics and Technology, things are just too complex.

\n

This makes it even more essential for roles & responsibilities to be sharply defined, so that existing staff know what is expected of them - and prospective joiners know what they’re getting into.

\n

It’s always personal

\n

How you go about defining things is really a matter of choice, with no hard and fast rules.

\n

A suggested approach can be seen in the document ‘Web Team Job Descriptions’ available for download on my site at diffily.com

\n

You should note how each description includes a clear summary of the role to be filled, as well as a list of important strategic & tactical responsibilities. A catalogue of expected skills is also included.

\n

An important thing to remember is that however technocratic such job descriptions may become, they are among the most delicate professional documents you will ever author.

\n

This is because each one will ultimately be assigned to named individuals, who will take them very personally indeed.

\n

Experience shows that whenever a dispute arises on a web team, the first things to be produced are job descriptions. As such, it is in your interest that each one be as clear and up to date as possible.

\n

Web people are humans too!

\n

The problem on many sites is that this never happens. Scale increases, new activities emerge, new people are hired - but roles and responsibilities remain untouched. It is somehow assumed by senior management that the ‘web guys’ will be able to work it out and fill in any gaps.

\n

But nature abhors a vacuum and web people are as human as anyone else. Before long, staff end up jostling for position along unclear reporting lines as kingdoms are forged and jealousies accumulate.

\n

Then one day - perhaps as the result of some minor incident - things fall apart and someone is given the inglorious task of patching things up.

\n

While uncontentious anachronisms may easily be fixed (for example, a Developer who has traditionally managed analytics but wants rid of it), it is common to find instances where change is vigorously resisted. Say a longstanding Content Producer who wants to retain control of design rather than surrender it to a newly hired UX Specialist.

\n

While retraining or incentivization can go a long way to easing Governance transformation, in the worst cases it may be necessary to throw everything in the air and start from scratch; perhaps by defining new roles and requiring existing staff to apply for a position.

\n

A better future?

\n

Inevitably, this is all quite painful.

\n

Sudden, enforced changes to a web team are as disruptive as any other part of a business, as good people who have worked hard over many years are edged-out.

\n

It is my belief that many organizations are working through a period of heightened stress at the moment as this legacy of inattention to online roles and responsibilities is finally put right.

\n

On the bright side this also means that disruptive change is likely to be less common in future, as web management becomes more professional.

\n

So, if you find yourself in a bit of a web-team warzone, don't be too down hearted. Join me for a webinar on June 11 at 1pm (CDT) where we’ll be discussing the issue of roles and responsibilities in more detail, including additional questions, such as: 

\n
    \n
  • How many people to have on your team and with what skills?
    • \n
  • How should people be organized?
    • \n
  • Who should have overall responsibility for web?
    • \n
\n

\n \n \n  

\n

Shane has over 14 years' experience in Web Governance & online operations. As author of the first practical guide to Web Governance ("The Website Manager's Handbook"), Shane has also been published by A List Apart, Smartinsights & Forrester Research. For lots of FREE Web Governance downloads, visit www.diffily.com

\n
\n

Why Content Governance Drives Engagement

\n

\nPosted by\nAhava Leibtag\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In honor of President’s Day, my husband and I took our three children to the American Museum of History, a branch of the Smithsonian in Washington, D.C. While we were putting our coats in lockers, I saw something that surprised me:

\n
\n

Does stash seem like a word that is in line with Smithsonian brand? Stash feels a little too irreverent to be a Smithsonian word. Yet, when I saw this sign, it became clear to me:

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n

Identifying Key Performance Indicators and Micro Conversions on B2B Websites

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:22 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

This past week I had the opportunity to talk to both the Tampa and Orlando City Groups of the Legal Marketing Association (LMA) Southeastern Chapter about getting value from their web analytics. As with any good analytics framework, there are some key things you can do to begin making meaningful changes to your websites based on data.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n

3 Tips for Preparing for a Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nStar Bazella\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:16 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Website redesign projects are all the rage in marketing today. According to recent studies, the vast majority of marketing departments have either just undergone a website redesign, or are just about to. However, many marketers can’t give an empirical reason for their redesign. They know their current website is “underperforming,” and that’s about it. Without clearly and empirically determining how and why your website is underperforming, a redesign is little more than a really expensive and stressful shot in the dark.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Q&A on the Basics of Web Accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n2/11/14 9:01 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

We get a lot of questions on web accessibility here at Siteimprove, and want to take this opportunity to answer as many of them as we can. This may be more of a review for you seasoned accessibility folks, but there’s a growing demand for this introductory information as more web professionals recognize the importance of accessibility. 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n
\n
\n
\n

How to Win Friends and Influence Your Web Team

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n2/5/14 8:52 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Stop me if you’ve heard this one: You’re the website manager, and you’re held responsible for the quality of your web content - but you have content contributors from other departments over whom you hold no real power. That means you’re held accountable for the quality of their work, but have no way to make them actually do it. If they decide not to fix issues that come up, it reflects poorly on you. Fortunately, there are ways to manage this situation! Since you don’t have administrative influence over these team members, you’ll have to rely on relational influence – which is better anyway.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

6 Ways to Catch Website Issues Before They're a Problem

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/28/14 9:04 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Issues with your website can be absolutely devastating. Despite any of the marketing momentum or client base that you've built up, you may find your traffic ranking and following drastically tanking due to website errors. Lag, bad links, a lack of accessibility and even outdated content can quickly damage a website's SEO and lose the faith of its readership. Luckily, there are some ways you can avoid these issues before they even become a problem.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

5 Ways to Determine Your Website's ROI

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/21/14 9:14 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Measuring the ROI of a website is incredibly important. At any time, you may be called upon to prove that the company's website is worth the investment, or even to defend your budget - and that could mean defending your salary, too. The ROI of a website isn't always as simple as presenting "expenses going out" and "profit coming in." Sometimes you may find yourself explaining your website's ROI to individuals who don't even know how to use the web let alone understand its value as a marketing tool. Before you can appropriately measure a website's ROI, upper management needs to have specific marketing, administrative and client service goals for the site in mind. Once you know exactly which metrics the website is being judged on, you can begin calculating the website's return.

\n
\n
\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Maintaining Your Website Saves Time and Headache

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/16/14 9:19 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

“I don’t have time to quality assure my site. I’m already swamped with too many other things, and that’ll just have to wait until life settles down a bit.” Sound familiar? Time management is a daily struggle for most website managers, and all too often they deal with pressing deadlines by turning a blind eye to the quality of their website content. Unsurprisingly, this usually doesn't go well. Here are three good reasons why you actually need to keep your site the cleanest when you’re buried under a heavy workload:

\n
\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Announces US Relocation

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/14/14 3:41 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove, the leading provider of Web Governance tools, has relocated their Minneapolis office due to rapid growth in 2013.

\n
\n
\n

On January 2, 2014, Siteimprove US moved into a new office located at 8000 Norman Center Drive, Suite 300, Minneapolis, MN 55437 as part of a major workforce expansion.

\n

Siteimprove’s Minneapolis branch grew significantly in 2013, adding more than 250 new customers and 13 employees.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n

4 Website Tasks You Should Outsource to Robots

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n12/23/13 9:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Every web team is strapped for time, but most have no idea how much time they waste doing things manually when automated options are readily available. Here are four ways you’re wasting time maintaining your organization’s website.

\n
\nRead More\n

About Siteimprove

\n

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.

Are you ready to manage smart-phone access on your website?

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n7/25/12 5:11 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

By taking a quick glance at mobile web statistics, we can see an obvious increase in mobile phone users. Every indication points to this trend only continuing to grow. According to an analysis by Morgan Stanley, it is estimated that the number of Internet users who access the Internet through mobile units will exceed the number of users who access the Internet from traditional computers in 2014. The analysis is from 2010 and whether the results will prove true in 2014 is hard to say, but larger and better screens on smart phones, more powerful processors and flat-rate data subscriptions have an influence on the process.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

On page optimization post panda: 3 tips to future-proof your website

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n7/18/12 5:24 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Google regularly updates the algorithm that calculates a page's relevance to a given search. Last year in February came the much debated panda update, which has since been updated many times, even as recently as April of this year. Having just returned from the Search Marketing Expo in London, we have lots of good ideas on how to ensure that the content on your website meets the new requirements.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web analytics: gathering qualitative and quantitative data

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n7/11/12 5:27 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In basic terms, most web analysis systems are based on quantitative data. This quantitative data contributes to general knowledge about the usage of a given website. Everything can then be broken down into numbers and graphs to be interpreted by the person responsible for the optimization of the website.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Want to understand accessibility? Participate!

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n7/4/12 10:37 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Why is it important to be able to use a webpage without using a computer mouse? How does it work when a web page text is enlarged? How does a screen reader interpret a web page? Get the answers to these questions and learn why and to whom this is important.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

User Feedback - Building a closer relationship with your users

\n

\nPosted by\nCamilla Simonsen\n

\n

\n6/27/12 10:41 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Communicating with your users online often comes in the form of one way communication. This makes it hard for you to gain insight into what users actually think about your website. In this blog details how user feedback helps build a closer relationship with users, based on a case study of a municipal website in Denmark the Siteimprove has carried out since December 2011.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Four good ideas on how to find the right keywords

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n6/20/12 10:48 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Keywords are at the very heart of search engine optimization and finding the right keywords can make or break your SEO success. It is therefore very important to find the right keywords to target. It is impossible to optimize your website for all interesting keywords, so you will want to start out with the most important ones. Here, we will give you four good ideas on how to find the right keywords.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n

Dive into search statistics

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n6/6/12 10:54 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Search statistics are not only essential for evaluating and maintaining the search function on your website, they are also useful for many other purposes. It is a free opportunity to learn about what your users expect from your website. Do you have the information users need? Is it well organized, and is it easy to click though to the pages that are most sought after?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Map your current web governance

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n5/30/12 10:57 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Many organizations talk about Web Governance, but what is it – and why should you care? Simply put, Web Governance is a general term for the system of policies and guidelines you use for making decisions about your organization’s web presence. This system may be ill-defined and poorly organized, but it’s important to realize that you already have Web Governance. Thus, it makes sense to start working with Web Governance by mapping your organization’s current state of Web Governance.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Tell users about your cookies

\n

\nPosted by\nMie Elmkvist Jensen\n

\n

\n5/23/12 11:04 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Online privacy is a global hot-button, with lawmakers pressuring organizations to more tightly regulate the information they gather from visitors. The European Union recently enacted legislation dubbed the "cookie directive" has organizations scrambling to make their websites compliant. Many organizations in the US may not realize that they need to comply with these rules if they intend to operate a website in the EU. For those of you who don't run multiple sites, these simple tips may give you a head start preparing for future US legislation.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n
